div2.p: Introduction (prooi/mion). This subject has been so often handled by our more experienced politicians that on the present occasion I may be excused if I venture to speak first.
kainou=, ‘fresh,’ ‘not previously handled,’ to be distinguished from ne/os, ‘young,’ ‘of recent development,’ though their uses overlap to some extent.

prou)ti/qeto. The Prytanes, having charge of the conduct of business in the Ecclesia, are said protiqe/nai gnw/mas, lo/gon, yh=fon, ‘to bring forward a subject for discussion or voting.’ The imperfect implies that their action is regarded as continuing throughout the debate. Cf. Isocr. de Pace 15 parelh/luqa a)pofanou/menos...peri\ w(=n oi( pruta/neis protiqe/asin. For the infinitive replacing the more usual accusative cf. Thuc. III.38 tw=n proqe/ntwn au)=qis peri\ *mutilhnai/wn le/gein.
tw=n ei)wqo/twn, sc. gnw/mhn a)pofai/nesqai.

a)pefh/nanto. The middle is regularly used with gnw/mhn in this sense. The constructions following e(/ws (except in clauses referring to a definite event in past time) are identical with the constructions of conditional clauses. Hence the past indicative here in dependence on a conditional sentence of an unfulfilled character.

a(\ gignw/skw. The verb might have been attracted into the imperfect to agree with the clause on which it depends, but the present is more appropriate as suggesting that the orator's opinion is independent of the conditions mentioned.
kai\, with the participial phrase, ‘though I am the first to rise.’

e)k tou= parelhluqo/tos. We should say ‘in time past.’ The Greek frequently shews a tendency to regard points of time in the past as starting-points and points of future time similarly as points
of arrival. So a)f' e(spe/ras (at eventide), a)po\ mesw=n nuktw=n (at midnight), ei)s au)/rion (to-morrow), ei)s tri/thn h(me/ran (on the third day). Similarly inf. § 2.

a)/n. It is a common practice to omit a)
 with the imperfect indicative of verbs implying obligation and the like, just as debebam is used in Latin with a protasis containing an unfulfilled condition. The reason is that the obligation was, at any rate in early times, regarded as really existing independently of the condition: e.g. in xrh=n de\ se/, ei)/per h)=sqa xrhsto/s, mhnuth
 gene/sqai, it really was the duty of the person addressed to give information, whether he was an honest man or not. (Such, at least, seems to be the origin of this usage.) In the present case the truth of the apodosis does manifestly depend upon that of the protasis, and in such cases a)
 is fairly often inserted.
§ 2-50 Discussion (a)po/deicis) including (1) sketch of the situation (dih/ghsis) §§ 2—12, (2) proposals (pro/qesis) §§ 13—30, and (3) arguments in their support (pi/steis) §§ 31—50.

§ 2-6 Do not despair. Remember that your misfortunes have arisen from your own slackness, so that you may hope to retrieve them by diligence (2). Remember again that when Sparta was at the height of her power we were able by dint of diligence to withstand her (3). Remember also the example of Philip. He did not throw up the game because the advantages were on our side; and now through his diligence they are all on his (4—6).
o(\ ga/r e)sti xei/riston. The paradox, repeated in Phil. 3. 5, serves to excite the hearers' curiosity from the outset.

poiou/ntwn u(mw=n. The genitive absolute, as frequently, contains an idea more important than that of the main clause to which it is attached: ‘the fact that the evil plight of your affairs is due to your neglect of all proper measures.’
pratto/ntwn. The subject of a participle used absolutely in the genitive is sometimes omitted when (1) it can be supplied easily from the context, or (2) it is indefinite.

gene/sqai refers of course to time which, in relation to e)lpi\s h)=n, is future. But after verbs and verbal phrases expressing hope the aorist infinitive is sometimes so employed. Cf. Thuc. IV.24 to\ *(rh/gion h)/lpizon r(a|di/ws xeirw/sasqai. Indeed the aorist, except in the indicative and in the infinitive and participle where these in some sense represent indicatives, carries no significance of time. a)\n must of course be taken with h)=n.

a)kou/ousi and a)namimnh|skome/nois are syntactically parallel: the former participle seems at first to agree with u(mi=n understood, but the subdivision of u(mi=n which appears in the second member with toi=s ei)do/sin au)toi=s makes it clear that a)kou/ousi is intended to apply only to toi=s mh\ au)toi=s ei)do/sin u(mw=n. Cf. Thuc. I.42 w(=n e)nqumhqe/ntes kai\ new/tero/s tis para\ presbute/rwn au)ta\ maqw/n.
au)toi=s, almost ‘by personal experience,’ with ei)do/sin.

h(li/khn ... w(s kalw=s . The double question, whether direct or reported, is a regular Greek idiom. Cf. Plato, Rep. 332 D h( ti/si ti/ a)podidou=sa te/xnh; Soph. El. 751 oi(=' e)/rga dra/sas oi(=a lagxa/nei kaka/. In instances like the present there is some doubt whether forms like h(li/kos and oi(=os are to be regarded (1) as used loosely for the dependent interrogative forms (o(phli/kos, o(poi=os, &c.), (2) as dependent exclamations, or (3) as strictly relative.
The vagueness of e)c ou(= xro/nos ou) polu\s allows us to suppose that the speaker alludes to the ‘Corinthian’ war which began in 395 B.C. or the ‘Boeotian’ which began in 378.
qea/shsqe is not by any means a mere synonym of i)dh=te: Demosthenes wishes his hearers not merely to perceive the fact, but also to contemplate it.
fulattome/nois. Participle used conditionally, parallel to a)\n o)ligwrh=te.
mhde\n is to be taken adverbially, the regular construction after fronti/zein being a genitive. Why not ou)de/n?
ta\ xwri/a, especially those mentioned just below.

to\n to/pon tou=ton, the shores of the Thermaic gulf. Notice that oi)kei=on and ku/klw| are predicative and belong to ei)/xomen: the position of ku/klw| in separation from the article prevents us from taking it as attributive, though it may be translated as if it were so (Liddell and Scott's view is untenable). See Introd., §§ 5, 6.
e)qnw=n, especially the Illyrians and Paeonians.
e)leu/qera is stronger than au)tonomou/mena, denoting complete independence of any foreign power: the words are often coupled.

th=s au(tou= xw/ras, objective genitive, as representing the dative after e)piteixi/zein: ‘fortified bases for operations against his territory.’ Note the direct reflexive form referring to the subject, not of the nearest verb (e)/xousi) but of the more remote: the indirect form (ou(=) is not much used in Attic prose and its place is taken either by the direct, as here, or by the simple personal pronoun (au)tou=) according to the amount of emphasis required.
e)/pracen, almost synonymous with e)poi/hsen, as in sup. § 2, and often. So far as they differ in meaning, poiei=n implies complete accomplishment of an act, while pra/ttein does not.
e)n me/sw|, as the prizes for athletic competitions were exposed in the arena.
kai\ ga/r toi, stronger than kai\ ga/r: in this connexion kai\ means ‘also’ (i.e. ‘in addition to other reasons’).
poihsa/menos. The participle is used in a modal sense, so that it is parallel in sense to the modal clause w(s a)\n...pole/mw|, and is therefore treated as parallel in syntax.
kai\ prose/xein k.t.e(., a hexameter verse, such as is very rarely found in Demosthenes.

§ 7-12 Profit by these lessons and you may still retrieve your losses and punish Philip (7). For his supporters would not all be sorry to see his fall. Only you must rouse yourselves at once (8). Consider his presumptuous and aggressive attitude (9). Is not mere shame enough to rouse you to immediate action? At present you listen eagerly enough to reports unfavourable to his success, but in action you are so slack that even if Philip were dead your attitude would make his successor equally formidable (10, 11). Indeed, unless you shew more vigour, even that favourable opportunity would not enable you to recover one of your lost cities (12).

e)pi\ th=s toiau/ths gnw/mhs, rather a remarkable use: we may suppose that e)pi\ with the genitive developed meanings in the following order—(1) on or over, (2) in charge of (frequently in the titles of officials, as o( e)pi\ th=s dioikh/sews), (3) in possession of. The last meaning appears inf. 9 and, with a slight modification, in the present passage. Cf. Dem. 21. 213 th\n gnw/mhn tau/thn, e)f' h(=s nu=n e)ste/. Render ‘to adopt a view like this.’
nu=n is sharply emphasised by its position at the end of the clause —‘even now, late as it is.’ Supply e)ge/nesqe with ou) pro/teron.

th\n ei)rwnei/an, ‘your false modesty,’ the article implies that it does exist. The ei)/rwn is a man who pretends to have defects which he has not; so Socrates was said ei)rwneu/esqai because in discussion he affected complete ignorance.
ei)sfe/rein, to bear his share of an ei)sfora/, a property-tax specially levied to meet particular emergencies, especially for the expenses of war.

e)n h(liki/a|. Athenian citizens were liable to military service between the ages of 18 and 60; but unless under exceptional
circumstances only those between 20 and 50 were called out for foreign service, and commonly only in part.
sunelo/nti, apparently a dative due to ellipse. Cf. Isaeus 4. 22 sunelo/nti polu\ to\ dia/feron.

In Xenophon we have a fuller phrase w(s sunelo/nti ei)pei=n (e.g. An. 3. 1. 38) in which it is easy to supply e)sti/—‘as one summing up the matter may say.’ aplw=s, if retained, is to be taken with gene/sqai u(mw=n au)tw=n; some commentators would omit it.
u(mw=n au)tw=n, ‘your own men’: we should look at the matter from the other side and say ‘your own masters.’
au)to\s me\n k.t.e(. Take au)to\s with poih/sein, ‘imagining that he himself will do nothing.’
u(pe\r au)tou=. Some read au(tou= here, but there is no emphasis to justify it. See on sup. 5.
qe/lh|. The regular form of the verb in Attic prose is e)qe/lein, but qe/lein is found in certain set phrases, such as the present.
katerra|qumhme/na, ‘lost by shirking’: for the force of kata\ cf. katakubeu/ein ‘to gamble away,’ katafronti/zein ‘to lose by taking thought.’
a)qa/nata, predicatively with pephge/nai.

misei= tis. The singular tis is here used in a sort of collective sense, ‘many a one.’ Similarly Thuc. III.111 kai/ tinas au)tw=n tw=n strathgw=n h)ko/ntise tis. Not infrequently tis is used with active verbs, like on in French, in substitution for a passive construction.
pa/nu, with oi)kei/ws rather than with dokou/ntwn.
a(/panta, ‘all the characteristics,’ ‘feelings’ or ‘impulses.’

a)postrofh/n , o(/poi a)postrafw=si, ‘rallying-centre’—apparently a metaphor from tactics. The alternative rendering ‘refuge’ does not suit the general sense so well. Cf. Thuc. IV.76 ou)/shs e(ka/stois dia\ braxe/os a)postrofh=s.
h)/dh, placed at the end for emphasis.
o(ra=te, indicative or imperative?

oi(=, with a)selgei/as, ‘to what lengths of outrage.’ Cf. Soph. El. 1035 oi(= m' a)timi/as a)/geis. So e)ntau=q' a)fiko/mhn kakou=, Aesch. Cho. 691, but the demonstrative form is generally ei)s tou=to or tosou=to: cf. Dem. 18. 22 ei)s tou=q' h(=ken a)naidei/as. The clause introduced by oi(= is epexegetic of to\ pra=gma.
o(/s, quippe qui, introducing a clause of causal character.

ou)x oi(=o/s e)sti, ‘is not the man to’: the use of the infinitive after a relative is curious, though it is common in the case of oi(=os and
o(/sos; it may perhaps have had its origin in the construction of toiou=tos (tosou=tos) w(/ste.

prosperiba/lletai, ‘is striving further to acquire.’ The metaphor was either from putting on a robe or from surrounding a quarry in the chase (cf. Dem. 304. 25 ta\ loipa\ periballo/menos): the latter view is supported by peristoixi/zetai.
kaqhme/nous, ‘sitting idle’; cf. Dem. 25. 10 ta\ d' u(me/ter' au)tw=n a)polwleko/tes kaqh=sqe.

e)peida\n ti/ ge/nhtai; Greek freely employs interrogatives in subordinate clauses and with participles. So i(/na ti/; (sc. ge/nhtai) ‘with what object?’ ti/ maqw/n; ‘on the ground of what knowledge?’
nh\ *di/a, frequently used, as here, in phrases put in the mouth of an imaginary interlocutor.

a)na/gkh, sc. ge/nhtai. The best MS. authority favours a)na/gkh h)=|, but the hiatus seems too harsh for Demosthenes, and we are left to choose between omitting h)=| (which may have arisen (1) from accidental duplication of the last letter of a)na/gkh or (2) from deliberate insertion by a copyist who desiderated a complete construction) and reading a)na/gkh tis h)=| with inferior MSS.
nu=n, ‘as things are,’ with xrh/, rather than with gigno/mena.

u(pe\r is omitted by Blass, in which case tw=n pragma/twn is objective genitive, representing accusative after ai)sxu/nesqai ‘to be ashamed at,’ as in Dem. 1. 27. The thought is repeated in much the same form in 8. 51.
ei)pe/ moi, a ‘petrified’ phrase, used not infrequently in addressing a plurality of persons: cf. Dem. 8. 74.

au(tw=n, for a)llh/lwn, as fairly often; cf. Phil. 3. 21 a)pi/stws kai\ stasiastikw=s e)/xousi pro\s au(tou\s oi( *(/ellhnes. For its use in reference to the second person, cf. Aeschines 3. 163 bou/lei se qw= fobhqh=nai kai\ xrh/sasqai tw=| au(tou= tro/pw|.
The orator is girding at the well-known curiosity of his countrymen, mentioned frequently in their literature, and in Acts 17. 21.
ge/noit' a)/n. The question is pointed by the abruptness of asyndeton.
dioikw=n, referring especially to Philip's intervention in the Sacred War.
ou) ma\ *di/), a)ll' a)sqenei= is the reply of a second imaginary Athenian. Each is seeking an excuse for putting off action.
ti\ pa/qh|, euphemistically for a)poqa/nh|, as commonly.
ou)de\ ... ou)=tos , ‘not the present Philip either’ (any more than his possible successor).
para/, in a causal sense, ‘by reason of’ (vulgarly ‘along of’), as in Dem. 18. 232 para\ tou=to ge/gonen ta\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn.
kai\ tou=to, sc. e)sti/, ‘there is also this fact’: tou=to is explained by the whole of the following sentence.
Some prefer to render ‘suppose even this to be the case’; but it is not easy to arrive at this sense.

be/ltion, sc. h(mw=n e)pimelei=tai. When a verb serves as predicate to more than one subject, it frequently agrees with the nearest subject only. This occurs sometimes even when the subjects are, as here, not co-ordinate; cf. Thuc. 1. 82 o(/soi w(/sper kai\ h(mei=s u(p' *)aqhnai/wn e)pibouleuo/meqa (sc. e)pibouleu/ontai). For the thought, cf. Aristoph. Clouds 587 sqq., and compare the modern Briton's pride in ‘muddling through’ difficulties in public affairs.
o)/ntes, equivalent to ei) ei)/hte, antithetic, verbally to w(s nu=n e)/xete, and in sense to a)phrthme/noi.

e)pista/ntes, as well as dioikh/saisqe, is modified by the a)/n; the sense is that of e)pistai=te kai\ dioik. Render ‘intervening’ as in Isocr. 167 D e)cai/fnhs e)pista\s toi=s gignome/nois. In this sense the word connotes suddenness or unexpectedness.
o(/pws bou/lesqe. We might rather expect bou/loisqe, as it seems more natural in this case that the speaker should conceive the wish as part of the imaginary conjuncture.

de/casqai, as denoting mere passive acceptance, gives a stronger force to the assertion than labei=n. Amphipolis is selected as the most important and most deeply regretted of former Athenian possessions in that quarter.

a)phrthme/noi, sc. tw=n pragma/twn (Liddell and Scott appear to supply a)llh/lwn, with which it is impossible to give a proper sense to tai=s paraskeuai=s), ‘far removed as you are from the field of action.’ Cf. Dem. 18. 59 a)parta=n to\n lo/gon th=s grafh=s. Those who would give the word a different sense fail to produce any parallel from Attic prose.

§ 13-15 I will now proceed to explain the size and character of the force which I think is needed to oppose Philip, and the best method of providing funds (13). But first I must ask you to suspend judgment till you have heard all, and not to charge me with a dilatory policy. It is not so necessary to insist on haste as to lay down a clear line of action which will enable us to hold on till
the end. Of my success in so doing you shall judge for yourselves (14, 15).

w(s me\n ou)=n k.t.e(. The clause belongs both to the genitives absolute and to le/gwn. The somewhat intricate order is partly due, as Weil observes, to the desire to emphasise e\toi/mws. Construe w(s dei= a(/pantas u(pa/rxein e)qe/lontas poiei=n e(toi/mws ta\ prosh/konta.
to\ plh=qos, because the principal idea in paraskeuh\ is that of troops. After o(/son and ou(/stinas we may supply a)palla/cai...oi)/omai again. Why is not the article used with po/rous?
w(s a)/n moi dokei= paraskeuasqh=nai . a)\n belongs to the infinitive, which represents an optative in oratio recta.
kai\ dh/, ‘straightway,’ an emphasised form (just as h)/dh is) of dh/, the original meaning of which was temporal. Again in Dem. 5. 9.
dehqei/s. The time-significance of the aorist participle is prominent—‘when I have first requested.’
tosou=ton, ‘only so much.’
kri/nate, the aorist of the definite act, whereas prolamba/nete refers to the continual intrusion of prejudice. pro/teron is pleonastic. The asyndeton gives weight.
e)c a)rxh=s should be taken with kainh/n, ‘an armament of a radically new character,’ which for that reason might be expected to require lengthy preparation.
a)naba/llein, ‘to delay,’ oftener in the middle voice. A distinction has been drawn on the ground that the active has a causal force, ‘to hinder others,’ but is hardly borne out by the examples.
taxu\ and th/meron are of course quoted from supposed speakers, and serve as objects to ei)po/ntes.
ei)s de/on, ‘to the purpose,’ as inf. § 40 and elsewhere.

th=| nuni\ bohqei/a|, ‘by despatching levies now.’ The force of the article is rather obscure: perhaps ‘the levy implied by those who cry taxu/.’ boh/qeia, a mere expedition, is contrasted with paraskeuh\ sunexh\s in § 32.

o(\s a)\n dei/ch|, sc. ei)s de/on le/gei, or perhaps rather le/cei in view of what follows. As the sentence proceeds, the thought slips insensibly from the general to the particular. Take po/sh and po/qen as well as ti/s (direct interrogatives for indirect, as often) with porisqei=sa; the three points are those noted above in § 13 ti/s : tro/pos :: po/sh : plh=qos :: po/qen : po/rous xrhma/twn.
Demosthenes seems to underrate Philip's powers of resistance.
e(/ws. Blass reads te/ws with some MS. support. But the use of te/ws as a relative is not proved.
tou= loipou=, gen. of ‘time within which,’ most frequently dependent on an adverb, as here on ou)ke/ti, but also in direct connexion with a verb.
mh\ not ou), because the participle is to be construed with the infinitive le/gein (not e)/xein, which, being simply reported, would require ou)).
e)pagge/lletai, ‘volunteers,’ regularly of a spontaneous offer or promise.
to\ pra=gma, i.e. my fulfilment of my promise, the detailed proposals which follow.

§ 16-18 We must have in readiness a fleet of 50 triremes, with transports for 500 cavalry and all needful cargo-boats, and we must be ready to embark ourselves (16). This will enable us to check Philip's frequent expeditions. We must make him understand that Athens can still rouse herself on occasion (17). Either this knowledge will keep him from aggressive acts, or we shall be able to catch him off his guard (18).

penth/konta. The whole fleet at the disposal of Athens was reckoned by Demosthenes (14. 13 and elsewhere, in 354 B.C.) at 300. But the present suggestion refers only to ships to be actually ready for immediate service and manned wholly by citizens.
ei)=ta without de\ after prw=ton me/n; de\ is inserted or omitted indifferently in such cases after ei)=ta and, as in § 3, after e)/peita.

au)tou\s first suggests the necessity for personal activity, which is enforced and defined in au)toi=s e)mba=sin. The following phrase is an amplification of e)gnwke/nai o(/ti pleuste/on e)sti/n. Do not however take w(s as equivalent to o(/ti and supply e)sti/: the ou(/tw shews that w(s is to be taken as its correlative, and with pleuste/on we must supply o)/n (acc. absol.). The phrase is of a fairly common type; cf. Thuc. VII.15 w(s kai\ tw=n stratiwtw=n kai\ tw=n h(gemo/nwn mh\ memptw=n gegenhme/nwn, ou(/tw th\n gnw/mhn e)/xete, Plato, Rep. 327 C w(s toi/nun mh\ a)kousome/nwn ou(/tws dianoei=sqe.

toi=s h(mi/sesi, assimilated in gender and number to the substantive which depends on it: cf. o( h(/misus tou= xro/nou (Dem. 20. 8), ai( h(mi/seiai tw=n new=n (Thuc. VIII.8): also the neuter is used as in Thuc. IV.83 to\ h(/misu tou= stra/tou.
The total of the knights being normally 1000, the number meant here is 500.
Inscriptions prove beyond doubt that triremes were used for the transport of horses.
ploi=a, ‘tenders’ for the transport of provisions &c.
e)pi/, ‘to meet.’

ta\s ... stratei/as . Note (1) that the demonstrative pronoun tau/tas is inserted between the article and its substantive: this, though contrary to the usual rule, may be done when a word or phrase attributive to the substantive follows the article and precedes the demonstrative (if another attribute follows the demonstrative, as here, the article is not repeated); cf. § 19 ta\s e)pistolimai/ous tau/tas duna/meis: and (2) that the words ei)s *pu/las k.t.e(. which are attributive to stratei/as have not the article repeated before them though they follow the substantive: this is admissible (a) when the words following the substantive are so closely connected with words preceding it that they form practically a single attribute, and (b) when the substantive has a distinctly verbal character and the attribute is adverbial in form.
au)tou=, i.e. *fili/ppou, with stratei/as.
The allusions are to Philip's operations in 352—351 B.C.: see Introd. §§ 6, 9.
parasth=sai, ‘to put a thing beside,’ and so ‘before’ a person; hence ‘to suggest’ a thought. The inferior MSS. have parasth=nai, ‘this thought must enter his mind.’
ei)s *eu)/boian, sc. w(rmh/sate, alluding to the successful expedition under Timotheus in 357 B.C.

ei)s *(ali/arton, sc. u(ma=s o(rmh=sai (or fasi\n may be placed between commas and treated as parenthetic), in reference to the assistance given by Athens to Thebes in 395, when the latter, with Argive and Corinthian allies, defeated Lysander. fasi\n, because the occurrence was of too remote a date to be treated as a matter of common knowledge.
ei)s *pu/las, in 352 B.C.; see Introd. § 6.

ou)/toi pantelw=s...eu)katafro/nhto/n e)stin, sc. to\ tou=to parasth=sai au)tw=|: poih/sait' a)\n tou=to, i.e. o(rmh/sait' a)/n. It is no contemptible gain to inspire Philip with this fear, even if you would not actually (if occasion required) carry out my suggestion. The expression is, however, decidedly obscure, and the opinion of commentators as to the exact meaning is far from harmonious.

The use of the optative with a)
 in the protasis of a conditional sentence is rare: it can only occur when the condition itself is
regarded as contingent upon some further condition: it is here equivalent to ei) ou(/tw diakei=sqe w(/ste ou)k a)
 poih/saite (sc. ei) de/oi). The selection of this form is probably due to the influence of a)
 o(rmh/saite, the sense of which is here repeated. Cf. Dem. 24. 154 ou)de\ spe/rma dei= kataba/llein, ou)d' ei) mh/ pw a)
 e)kfu/oi, ‘even if (supposing you did so) it would not grow yet’ (Goodwin, M.T. 506—7).
It is certainly best to understand the sentence as a parenthesis, as the following i(/na-clause depends most satisfactorily on dei=... parasth=sai.
eu)trepei=s, sc. o)/ntas; the participle is not often omitted after verbs of knowing and perceiving, but cf. inf. § 41 a)\n e)n *xerronh/sw| pu/qhsqe *fi/lippon.
paridw/n, ‘overlooking,’ looking past, instead of at a thing, somewhat like periidei=n.
mhdeno/s, neuter; not ou)deno/s, because of the dependence on i(/na and the conditional character of the whole sentence.
a)\n e)ndw=| kairo/n, ‘if he offers us a chance’; so Aristoph. Knights 847 labh\n ga\r e)nde/dwkas. The inferior MSS. give kairo/s, ‘if opportunity allows.’

§ 19-22 Before we prepare the force I have mentioned, we must establish an offensive force to maintain the war continuously. It must not be a mere paper army of mercenaries, but must contain citizens (19). I will go into detail. Only do not make your usual mistake of passing decrees on a vast scale and leaving them wholly inoperative: better to make small plans and carry them out (20). I suggest a force of 2000 footmen and 200 horse, of whom a quarter must be citizens (21); also ten ships of war. I will explain why that will suffice (22).
dedo/xqai...pareskeua/sqai. The resolution must be maintained and the preparations kept up: that is the force of the perfect.
pro\ de\ tou/twn, in spite of the prw=ton in § 16. The latter refers to order of importance, the present words to priority in immediate urgency.

sunexw=s, cf. § 32 paraskeuh=| sunexei=. The orator insists on this point, because the usual method of conducting warfare in Greece was simply to despatch troops (boh/qeiai) for a particular purpose and allow them to return on the completion of the immediate operations.

mh/ moi, supply a transitive imperative (e.g. ei)/phte or ei)pa/tw
tis) to govern the accusative; cf. Aristoph. Ach. 345 mh/ moi pro/fasin.
e)pistolimai/ous, ‘paper armies,’ properly ‘existing (only) in letters or despatches to our allies or to our generals.’ For the order of the words see on § 17.

th=s po/lews e)/stai, ‘shall really belong to the city’ in contrast with the armies of mercenaries, which easily got out of control and sought their own profit more readily than that of their employers: see § 24.

ka)
 u(mei=s. The kai\ is needed both as a copula to connect pei/setai with e)/stai, and with a)
 to balance the following clauses (ka)
 being equivalent to e)a/n te). We may say then that the first ka)
 stands for kai\ ka)/n, which is avoided for euphony.

kaq' e(/kaston tou/twn, for tau=ta kaq' e(/kaston or e(/kaston tou/twn. It is common to find kaq' e(/kaston thus treated as a single word and serving as object to a verb. Similarly in Phil. 3. 22 kaq' e(/n) ou(twsi\ periko/ptein kai\ lwpodutei=n tw=n *(ellh/nwn.
The promise made in xwri\s is not strictly fulfilled, as the answers to ti/s and po/sh are combined in §§ 21, 22; pw=s e)qelh/sei is dealt with in §§ 24—27, and the matter of trofh\ in §§ 28, 29.

ce/nous me\n le/gw. We may suppose that the sentence was intended to proceed pentakosi/ous kai\ xili/ous, poli/tas de\ pentakosi/ous; but the speaker interrupts himself to insert a parenthesis forestalling objections based on the smallness of the force suggested, and does not resume the construction. The ce/noi are mentioned first as connecting this sentence with what precedes—‘I do propose mercenaries’ (though what I have just said might lead you to think otherwise).

poih/sete. All the manuscripts here give the subjunctive poih/shte; but editors are for the most part agreed that the future indic. is necessary. See Goodwin, M.T. 283. On the whole the best view seems to be that the subjunctive in independent clauses introduced by o(/pws mh\ is admissible, if at all, only when the sense to be given is that of cautious assertion or fear, not, as here, of exhortation. Note that in positive independent clauses introduced by o(/pws the subjunctive is never found.
pa/nt' e)la/ttw, with asyndeton, as fairly often in explanatory sentences.
e)pi\ tw=| pra/ttein, ‘when it comes to action’; e)pi\ has its local significance.
e)la/ttw, sc. tou= de/ontos. With fai/nhtai supply o)/nta, not ei)=nai (‘proves’ not ‘seems’).
tou\s pa/ntas, ‘in all.’
h(=s a)/n tinos, for h(/stinos a)/n, forming with the subjunctive a conditional relative clause.

h(liki/as, see on § 7. The lists of citizens kept for military purposes were identical with the lists made annually of youths admitted to citizenship in each deme at the age of 18. Each year was kept separate under the name of its a)/rxwn e)pw/numos, and when troops were required it was usual to call out certain years (e.g. Dem. 3. 4 tou\s me/xri pe/nte kai\ tettara/kont' e)tw=n), though sometimes given years were only called out in part. The first three Solonian classes served as hoplites, the Thetes as light troops.
takto/n, instead of the usual practice in boh/qeiai.
a)llh/lois, as diade/xesqai ‘to succeed’ is followed by a dative.
i(ppe/as, governed by le/gw, as are i(ppagwgou\s and trih/reis.
tou)la/xiston, ‘at least,’ adverbial, as frequently.

w(/sper, correlative to to
 au)to
 tro/pon, i.e. xro/non takto
 e)k diadoxh=s.

taxei/as, i.e. fighting vessels, distinguished by this epithet from the transports which might also (see § 16) be trih/reis. They are to convoy the latter. The transports, except the i(ppagwgoi/, are not mentioned, but their necessity is assumed.
Philip's fleet was of recent origin and not powerful, but the exploits of his cruisers had already caused some alarm: see § 34.
thlikau/thn, ‘only so large,’ ‘so small.’

tou\s strateuome/nous ought to include the whole force. Either Demosthenes is speaking very loosely, or the MSS. are wrong and we should read tou\s strateusome/nous (the article being used idiomatically, as in § 23 th\n paratacome/nhn) or sustrateuome/nous (without tou/s).

§ 23-24 I think this force sufficient because for the present we cannot meet Philip in regular warfare but must content ourselves with harassing him (23). And citizens must serve, because in the past mixed forces of citizens and mercenaries have done good service, whereas now that mercenaries are employed alone they devote their attention to their own interests (24).
tosa/uthn takes its construction from the preceding sentence (sc. a)poxrh=n oi)=mai).

th\n used, as frequently, with the future participle expressing purpose, where definiteness seems to us to be out of the question.
The idiom seems to be due originally to the speaker's having a definite conception of what is required to fulfil the purpose. Cf. Xen. An. II. 4. 5 o( h(ghso/menos ou)dei\s e)/stai.
paratacome/nhn, of regular fighting, or pitched battles; so para/tacis in Phil. III. 49.
lh|steu/ein, ‘make forays,’ like pirates by sea or freebooters on land; so lh|stei/a of guerilla warfare in Thuc. IV.41, VIII. 40.

th\n prw/thn, indistinguishable from to\ prw=ton in meaning. There is ellipse of some feminine substantive which cannot be recovered, as in many similar phrases, e.g. th\n taxi/sthn, dia\ kenh=s, a)po\ th=s i)/shs.
tre/fein, infinitive of the imperfect=o(/ti e)/trefe; so also sustrateu/esqai. The allusion is to the ‘Corinthian’ war of 394 to 387 B.C.
Polystratus is only otherwise known as having received a public honour on the request of Iphicrates (Dem. 20. 84).

Iphicrates was one of the most distinguished of Athenian generals and a man of original talent. He dealt the first blow to the traditional supremacy of heavy-armed troops by organising a force of mercenaries with an equipment intermediate between that of hoplites and that of peltasts; and with his light troops in 390 B.C. he cut to pieces a Lacedaemonian mo/ra (600 hoplites), an exploit loudly applauded by his countrymen.

Chabrias superseded Iphicrates as Athenian general in the Corinthian war, but was more famous for his defeat of the Lacedaemonian fleet at Naxos in 376. He was killed in the siege of Chios (357 B.C.).
a)kou/wn, ‘by hearsay’; the sense does not allow us to regard the participle as taking the place of an object-clause.
e)ni/kwn may refer only to the defeat of the mo/ra, as the imperfect of nika=n is often used of a single battle where we might have expected the aorist.

u(mi=n. The dative (of persons) is frequently used where a possessive genitive would stand and give almost the same sense. The difference is that the dative brings the person into relation with the verb instead of with the substantive—‘you have your mercenaries serving.’
tou\s fi/lous. Isocrates, speaking in 356 B.C. (8. 46), makes the same complaint. Such bodies of mercenaries used to plunder friendly territory as readily as hostile.
e)xqroi\ makes the hostility of Macedon a more fundamental matter than pole/mioi, which simply implies the existence of war at the moment.
paraku/yanta, ‘after a mere glance.’ The word is almost confined to comedy (especially of peeping through a window), and suits the satirical character of the passage.

pro\s *)arta/bazon, referring to Chares, who, when despatched by Athens against the rebellious allies in 356 B.C., enrolled himself and his mercenaries under A., then in rebellion against Artaxerxes, in order to secure pay, which Athens did not provide with regularity. It was perhaps the importance of Chares to Athens which led Demosthenes to throw the blame more on the men than on their commander in this passage.
ma=llon, sc. h)\ pro\s to\n th=s po/lews po/lemon.
ei)ko/tws is frequently placed at the end of a sentence when a sentence in explanation of it follows.

§ 25-27 You must provide pay for your mercenaries and send citizens with them to see that they do their duty. At present you say you are at war with Philip (25), but of your elected military officers only one goes to the front, while the rest are busy with ceremonies at home (26). Your principal officers in the field ought all to be Athenians (27).
pori/santas and parakatasth/santas are participles indicating the means by which the action of the verb (a)felei=n) to which they are attached is to be brought about.
oi)kei/ous, ‘of your own,’ i.e., as the preceding context determines, ‘of your own number.’
e)po/ptas, ‘overseers,’ the word is used in a sense derived immediately from its most literal meaning, and without reference to its technical use in connexion with the Eleusinian mysteries.
ge/lws, ‘ridiculous’ (geloi=on). Cf. Dem. 19. 332 komidh=| ge/lws e)sti\ kathgorei=n e)kei/nou tou=ton.

ou)x h(mei=s ge, ‘not we.’ The primary function of ge\ is to emphasise h(mei=s: at the same time ge\ is regularly employed in a reply in which something is supplied from the words of the previous speaker (as here ei)rh/nhn a)/gomen) to complete the construction.
War had been going on more or less since 357 B.C.

e)xeirotonei=te. The tense is curious; either it ‘implies a retrospect over the whole duration of the war’ (Sandys) or the imperfect of ‘narrative giving place to description,’ as Rutherford
expresses it. For the latter, cf. Dem. 19. 25 ei)=ta to/t' ou)k e)/leges paraxrh=ma tau=t) ou)d) e)di/daskes h(ma=s. Neither seems to me satisfactory, and I suspect that Demosthenes really used the present.
Military officers at Athens, unlike most officials, were appointed by election, not by lot.

There was one taci/arxos (infantry) and one fu/larxos (cavalry) for each tribe. The supervision of the strathgoi\ and (for cavalry) the i(/pparxoi was in earlier times exercised jointly, but recently separate provinces had been assigned to the several strathgoi/, so that here we find one only in charge of the war.
pe/mpousi, ‘marshal’; the play on words between this and e)kpe/myhte is obvious enough.
i(eropoiw=n, a board appointed by lot to supervise the quadrennial festivals (except the Panathenaea); see Aristotle, *)aq. *pol. 54. 6.

The i(/pparxoi were in charge of the cavalry who took part in the Panathenaic procession, as shewn on the frieze of the Parthenon. Probably the hoplites who also marched in that procession were similarly under the direction of their own officers. A ceremonial inscription of 340 B.C. associates the generals and taxiarchs with the i(eropoioi/.
tou\s phli/nous, sc. a)nqrw/pous or a)ndri/antas or, less probably, tacia/rxous kai\ fula/rxous; referring to the terra-cotta figurines of which so many have been discovered in recent years.
ei)s th\n a)gora/n, i.e. in the case of the figures, for sale, in the case of the officers, for mere display on ceremonial occasions, the a)gora\ being the principal scene of these pageants.
e)xrh=n, like prosh=ken, e)/dei, of an obligation in present time not fulfilled.

i(/pparxon, singular, in the view of most authorities, because one of the two i(/pparxoi necessarily remained at Athens to take part in ceremonies. But (1) it is not clear that this was the case; on the contrary it is probable à priori that in the case of important campaigns both hipparchs would serve abroad, each commanding his five tribes; (2) even if that was the case, the singular is not necessary, as the plural might quite naturally be used of successive officers, and (3) all MSS. except S give the plural. (Voemel's contention that the plural would require the article is untenable.)

a)/rxontas resumes tacia/rxous and i(ppa/rxous under a more general term, oi)kei/ous (used predicatively) being parallel to and practically
synonymous with par' u(mw=n. This seems better than to take a)/rx. oi)k. in apposition to the preceding substantives.

i(/n' h)=n. In final clauses introduced by i(/na, o(/pws, or w(s a past tense of the indicative is regularly used when the main clause contains a past indicative expressing what is not the case (an unfulfilled wish, the protasis or the apodosis of a conditional sentence): sometimes also when the main verb is not a past indicative but the significance is of a similar character (e.g. Eur. Hec. 814 ti/...peiqw\... ou)de\n...spouda/zomen...manqa/nein, i(/n' h)=n pote pei/qein a(/ tis bou/loito, where ti/ ou)de\n spouda/zomen is nearly equivalent in meaning to e)xrh=n spouda/zein).

w(s a)lhqw=s: so w(s e(te/rws, w(sau/tws; so far as meaning goes, the w(s may be ignored. Three explanations of the origin of this idiom have been suggested: (1) w(s is exclamatory; (2) w(s is relative with an ellipse w(s a)\n a)lhqw=s e)/xoi or ei)/poi tis; (3) w(s is a survival of a declension of the article without t, agreeing with a)lhqw=s, it being probable that adverbs in -w=s were originally cases of adjectives. The last explanation is probably the best.

The suggestion clearly implied here, though Demosthenes refrains from making a definite proposal, is that all the superior officers of forces employed by Athens should be appointed by the state. We infer that at present the strathgo\s in charge of operations organised his command according to his own pleasure.

ei)s *lh=mnon. This hipparch is distinct from the two regular officers mentioned above. He was a comparatively unimportant officer who commanded a cavalry corps stationed in that island (Aristotle, *)aq. *pol. 61. 6).
*mene/laon, reasonably identified with a certain Pelagonian from Upper Macedonia, who assisted Timotheus in his campaigns.
i(pparxei=n, not in its special sense, but simply ‘to be in command of the cavalry.’
to\n a)/ndra. The accusative and the dative seem to be used indifferently after me/mfomai of the person blamed.

o(/stis a)\n h)=|, after e)/dei, where one might expect o(/stis ei)/h. The form appropriate to primary sequence is preferred because the significance of the sentence is that of a general statement in present time.

§ 28-29 Now for the financial question. This force will require an annual expenditure of ninety odd talents, allowing no pay beyond mere rations for the men (28). They will be able to obtain
from their campaign sufficient to render further pay unnecessary: I am ready to guarantee this (29).

kai\ perai/nw. The kai\ marks the parallel between the desire of the audience and the procedure of the speaker—w(/sper poqei=t' a)kou=sai, ou(/tw kai\ perai/nw. The present is used, as often, of an intention to be fulfilled immediately. dh\ simply emphasises the demonstrative.
xrh/mata, nominative used absolutely; or perhaps rather with trofh\ in apposition, the latter word determining the construction of the sentence.
e)/stin, ‘amounts to,’ more usually gi/gnetai.

trofh\ properly includes sithre/sion (rations) and misqo/s; here it is explicitly confined to the former, and the soldiers are expected to find their own pay in the shape of plunder: a somewhat dangerous plan, in spite of Demosthenes' readiness to guarantee that only hostile territory will be plundered. me\n marks the first of the two topics (trofh\ and misqo/s), the latter being dealt with in § 29.

pro/s, adverbial, ‘in addition,’ ‘over,’ as often. The mikro/n ti is exactly two talents, as may be seen by adding together the following totals, which of course give the annual expenditure. The amount is calculated on the basis of 2 obols a head per diem; the horseman receives more (a drachma per diem) in consideration of the feed of his horse.
tosau=q' e(/tera, ‘the same amount’ (40 talents): the same words are sometimes used also with the meaning ‘twice as much.’

a)formh/n, ‘provision’ (not as Liddell and Scott). The construction is either (1) ei)/ tis oi)/etai (to\) sithre/sion u(pa/rxein (ei)=nai) mikra\n a)f., ‘that the supplying of rations only is but a small provision,’ or (2) ei)/ tis oi)/etai sithre/sion u(pa/rxein mikra\n a)f., ‘that rations are but a small provision.’ (1) is preferable, as with (2) it is difficult to find a reason for the choice of u(pa/rxein in preference to ei)=nai.
tou=to, the provision of rations.

prosporiei=tai, ‘will provide for itself in addition.’ The best MSS. give the active, which may be defended on the ground that such ‘provision’ is in effect for the state, inasmuch as the state is thereby relieved of the necessity for finding misqo/s.
e(/toimos without ei)mi/, a form of expression which is curiously frequent (of course ei)mi\ is freely omitted when e)gw\ is present).

po/qen. Some place a comma only after gene/sqai, regarding
po/qen as used here for o(po/qen (cf. § 15). The doubt is one which often arises, and which can only be solved by considering whether the direct or indirect question better suits the passage in hand. Perhaps the safest way is to treat the question as independent wherever possible.

It is unfortunate that the financial proposals have not been preserved. Dionysius of Halicarnassus makes the speech end here and treats the following sections as a separate speech. His view is completely refuted by the absence of any peroration for the first speech or exordium for the second. Also he provides no antecedent for tau=ta in the next sentence, leaving it meaningless. Without entering into the origin of his mistake, it is enough to say here that the great majority of scholars have maintained the unity of the whole speech as we have it.

p.hi: Such are my proposals, for which I hope you will vote.

div2.p: h(mei=s includes friends or public officials, or both: it is noted that Demosthenes never uses the plural of himself alone.

e)pixeirotonh=te, ‘you put to the vote,’ attributing to the e)kklhsi/a what is properly the act of its officer, the e)pista/ths. For this reason, and because the aorist is the regular tense after e)peidh\ and e)peida/n, I am inclined to follow Tournier in reading e)pixeirotonh/sh| (sc. o( e)pista/ths). The force of e)pi\ is to give a transitive sense to an intransitive verb, as in e)palhqeu/ein. There is no sound support for Liddell and Scott's rendering ‘sanction by vote’: also ta\s gnw/mas means ‘all the proposals before you,’ i.e. my own and others which may be made; and they cannot all be sanctioned.

The MSS. all support a(
 (a(\ a)
) u(mi=n a)re/skh|; but the necessity of Dobree's emendation is shewn by the following final clause. The object of xeirotonh/sete must be th
 e)mh
 gnw/mhn, as Demosthenes would not admit the same purpose in a vote given for another proposal which might be of a very different character.
e)n tai=s e)pistolai=s. Cf. Livy XXXI. 44 Athenienses quidem litteris verbisque, quibus solis valent, bellum adversus Philippum (i.e. Philip V.) gerebant.

§ 31-32 Consider the geography of the Aegean. Philip undertakes enterprises in the North at seasons when natural causes prevent our moving thither (31). We must therefore have a permanent force in the North to reach him easily (32).
to\n to/pon, ‘the geographical position.’

pneu/masin and w(/rais are instrumental with prolamba/nwn. ‘Philip
generally effects his object by making use of the winds and the seasons to get the start of you.’ The following clause coupled to this by kai\ (almost=‘that is’) gives the same sense in a more definite form.
fula/cas, ‘watching (and waiting) for’ (like threi=n in Thuc. III.22 and elsewhere). Cf. Antiphon 145. 48.

tou\s e)thsi/as, sc. a)ne/mous, ‘the annual winds’ or ‘trade-winds’ which blew from the North over the Aegean from the end of July to the end of September, and would therefore impede the Athenians in any attempt to reach Macedonia or their possessions near Macedonia. In winter the use of ships, and indeed almost any warlike operation, was practically suspended in Greece.

a)\n, with dunai/meqa, a condition (e.g. ei) de/oi) being implied. (See on § 18 ei) mh\ poih/sait' a)/n.) The negative is mh\ because of the idea of purpose in the clause: in a relative clause expressing purpose, as in many other cases, the optative with a)\n is almost equivalent to the future indicative.

bohqei/ais, see on § 19 for the contrast between this and the sunexh\s (permanent) paraskeuh/. *paraskeuh/ and du/namis are partial synonyms denoting the same thing, but with different connotations: the army is a paraskeuh/ in relation to Athens, a du/namis in regard of its operations.

xeimadi/w|. Of the datives, *lh/mnw| and the following are objects of xrh=sqai, xeimadi/w| is predicative, in apposition to them, and th=| duna/mei is dativus commodi: xeimadi/w|, singular, because only one of the places mentioned would actually be used (kai\ is frequently employed in Greek where we should prefer a disjunctive form). The islands mentioned were given up by Athens at the end of the Peloponnesian War, but recovered before the peace of Antalcidas (387 B.C.). The other islands are e.g. Skiathos and Peparethos.
tou/tw|, chosen in preference to e)kei/nw|, because the region, though geographically ‘remote,’ is ‘near’ in discourse, as mention of it is implied in the mention of the three islands named.
xrh/, sc. u(pa/rxein.
th\n w(/ran, ‘the seasonable period’ for sailing etc.; i.e. the summer: compare the use of ‘the season’ which is arising in English.
pro/s, ‘close to.’ The object is to make descents on the seaboard of Macedonia, and to harass the commerce of Philip's ports.

§ 33-34 If you establish such a force, leaving sufficient discretion to the commander (33), you will prevent Philip from plundering your allies on the sea and avoid any repetition of the recent aggressions of his fleet (34).
a(/, cognate accusative, used practically as an adverb; cf. Phil. 3. 74 ti/ xrh/sesqe (*qhbai/ois); notice that the relative is here put parallel with a direct (for indirect) interrogative, po/te.
para\ to\n kairo/n, ‘alongside of the right moment,’ so ‘when occasion arises.’ Cf. Dem. 18. 13 tai=s e)k tw=n no/mwn timwri/ais par' au)ta\ ta/dikh/mata xrh=sqai.
ku/rios, predicative (the article belongs to the participle); ‘the man who is made responsible for this by you.’
ge/grafa, ‘have put down in my proposal.’

e)ntelh=, best taken with th\n du/namin (in apposition to the preceding accusatives), ‘the whole force in its entirety’: some prefer to regard it as agreeing with the preceding words, and make pa=san th\n du/namin the object of kataklei/shte. For the infinitive after this verb in this sense cf. Andoc. 3. 7 xi/lia ta/lanta...no/mw| kateklei/samen e)cai/reta ei)=nai tw=| dh/mw|.

tami/ai kai\ poristai/, both are official designations, though not here used in their official sense. Most of the more important public offices at Athens had their special tami/ai (treasurers); poristai\ seem only to have been appointed occasionally to raise extraordinary revenue. As poristai\ the Athenians are to raise the money required, as tami/ai to keep control of it and disburse it as required.
pau/sesqe begins the apodosis.
lo/gon zhtou=ntes, a less technical expression for the eu)/qunai.
ple/on ou)de\n poiou=ntes, ‘attaining nothing’; the phrase is a causative counterpart to ple/on e)/xein.
a)po/, ‘with resources drawn from’: cf. Thuc. I.99 hu)/ceto to\ nautiko\n a)po\ th=s dapa/nhs h(\n e)kei=noi cumfe/roien.

a)/gwn kai\ fe/rwn, ‘plundering,’ either with personal object (cf. Dem. 18. 230 a)nti\ tou= tou\s lh|sta\s h(ma=s fe/rein kai\ a)/gein) or with accusative of the district ravaged. Originally a)/gein was probably used of driving off cattle, fe/rein of removing portable property.
e)/cw, ‘free from,’ ‘beyond the reach of.’

ou)x w(/sper, a curious idiomatic construction, originating probably in ellipse. The history of the usage may be somewhat as follows:— in such a phrase as kakw=s pa/sxw ou)x w(/sper to\ pro/teron e)/pasxon the second verb could easily be left to the understanding of the
hearer. An ellipse arose in this way, and this ellipse not being distinctly realised the relative w(/sper might be provided with a construction giving the same sense, but not corresponding exactly to the main clause, e.g. kakw=s pa/sxw ou)x w(/sper to\ pro/teron hu)daimo/noun. This practice would then be extended, until, as we find often in classical Attic, ou)x w(/sper could be used almost anywhere with a force which may be rendered by ‘whereas on the contrary.’ If we must supply a construction (which Demosthenes would not have been conscious of omitting) it would run somewhat like this— ou)k (e)n tw=| kakw=s pa/sxein) w(/sper (h)=te) to\n parelqo/nta xro/non (o(/te). Cf. Plato, Symp. 179 E e)poi/hsan to\n qa/naton au)tou= u(po\ gunaikw=n gene/sqai, ou)x w(/sper (=ou) poiou=ntes w(/sper e)poi/hsan o(/te) *)axille/a... e)ti/mhsan.

The events alluded to in the following words are not otherwise known, though Aeschines speaks (2. 72) of Philip as making efforts for Lemnos and Imbros before 353 B.C. The poli=tai would be citizens holding cleruchies in the islands.
ploi=a, evidently merchant-ships, probably corn-ships carrying cargoes to the Athenian market.

trih/rh, the Paralos, which was apparently seized when touching at Marathon, as the sacred trireme regularly did on the way to Delos with the qewri/a. This vessel and the Salaminia were used for state purposes as despatch-boats and in particular for religious occasions.
The asyndeton marks emotion, as does the rhythm (the words ta\ teleutai=(a)...xw/ras form two anapaestic dimeters).
ei)s, of future time; see on § 2.

§ 35-37 Your public festivals are punctually held. Why then are your expeditions always too late (35)? Because all arrangements for the former are properly made in good time, but in military matters there is no ready-made organisation: everything has to be done at the last moment, and the consequent delay involves failure (36). Procrastination means final loss of opportunity. Your existing troops are useless in an emergency. And to Philip can write contemplucuily of us as he does to the Euboean: (37).

kai/toi with me/n. This method of bringing out an inconsistency by the coordination of clauses with me\n and de\ is very commonly employed: in most cases the corresponding English exhibits subordination of the me\n-clause, which may be introduced by ‘though,’ ‘whereas,’ or ‘while.’
*panaqhnai/wn . ta\ mega/la *p. were held in the third year of each Olympiad, early in August; ta\ mikra\ at the same season in each of the intervening years.

*dionusi/wn . ta\ mega/la *d. were held yearly at the end of March, with the most important of the dramatic exhibitions; ta\ kat' a)grou\s in December; ta\ e)n *li/mnais (more commonly known as ta\ *lh/naia) in January. The Anthesteria, also held in honour of Dionysus, may be included.
tou= kaqh/kontos xro/nou. The genitive of time is used rather loosely; for indicating a date the dative is the usual form.
deinoi/, ‘experts,’ contrasted with i)diw=tai, ‘persons without special knowledge or experience’: both words are complementary to the predicate.

oi( ... e)pimelou/menoi , i.e. in the case of the Dionysia the a)/rxwn e)pw/numos, in that of the Panathenaea the ten specially appointed a)qlo/qetai. Taking these words as subject, la/xwsi is used absolutely—‘are appointed by lot to be such.’ It seems quite needless to depart from the reading of S.
ou)d' ei)s e(/na, a more emphatic expression than ei)s ou)de/na.
o)/xlon, colloquially ‘fuss.’

e)/xei, ‘bring with them’: as subject to this verb we may supply a(\ from ei)s a(/; but note that when in English we have a relative clause containing two or more members in which the syntactic function of the relative is not the same, Greek idiom does not repeat the relative, but if for any reason it is desired to repeat the thing signified by the relative, the personal (or sometimes demonstrative) pronoun is used instead. Cf. Phil. III. 47 *lakedaimo/nioi, oi(\ qala/tths me\n h)=rxon kai\ gh=s a(pa/shs...u(fi/stato d' ou)de\n au)tou/s. In reality such a member is an independent clause. Considering what we know of the elaborateness of some of the Athenian festivals, the statement in this sentence is probably little, if at all, exaggerated.
For Philip's capture of the towns mentioned see Introd. §§ 5, 6. Potidaea is mentioned last as most important.

xorhgo/s. The xorhgi/a and gumnasiarxi/a belonged to the class of e)gku/klioi (regular) lh|tourgi/ai, distinguished from those which were only imposed as occasion required. They were discharged in rotation by members of the several tribes. The xorhgo\s had to bear the expense of providing and training choruses for the drama and for other choral competitions; the gumnasi/arxos was responsible for the cost of athletic contests.
ti/ labo/nta (sc. e(/kaston) ti/ dei= poiei=n. For two interrogatives in one clause cf. § 3; note that those interrogatives which are connected with the same verb are coupled by a copula.
A striking effect of rapidity is obtained as we approach the climax of this part of the speech by the free use of asyndeton and by the multiplication of short coordinate clauses.
a)nece/taston and a)o/riston are predicative.
a(/m' a)khko/ame/n ti kai/, ‘it is only when we have received news that.’ Coincidence in time is frequently expressed by means of coordinate clauses.

trihra/rxous. These were appointed both in earlier and in later times in regular succession, whether their services were required at the time or not. It appears that before the time of this speech there had arisen (whether by deliberate change of policy or by mere laxity) a practice of leaving the appointment of trierarchs until it had been decided to employ ships on active service. If any citizen called upon to act as trierarch claimed that a wealthier citizen had been passed over he might demand that the latter should either undertake the duty in his place or exchange properties with him (a)nti/dosis). The strathgoi\ were responsible for the appointment of trierarchs and for the supervision of a)ntido/seis.
poiou/meqa, ‘cause.’

tou\s metoi/kous. Resident aliens at Athens were liable to military service, the wealthier as hoplites, the rest as seamen. Freedmen were politically in the same position as me/toikoi, and were known as xwri\s oi)kou=ntes because they no longer dwelt with their masters.
au)tou\s pa/lin, sc. e)mbai/nein.
a)ntembiba/zein, ‘to put substitutes on board.’ These substitutes, it seems, would be either slaves or hirelings, provided by the citizens liable for service.
proapw/leto, gnomic aorist. The reading of S is proapo/lwle to\ e)f' o(\ a)\n, of the other MSS. proapo/lwlen e)f' a(\ a)\n.
tw=n pragma/twn, either subjective, ‘opportunities offered by events,’ or objective, ‘opportunities for action.’
ei)rwnei/an, ‘feigned incapacity’; cf. § 7.
a(\s ... duna/meis , as usually, for ai( duna/meis a(\s. The allusion is to the forces of mercenary soldiers spoken of in § 24.
oi(=ai/ te, sc. ou)=sai, the regular participial construction with verbs of proving.

ei)s tou=q' u(/brews, see on § 9 oi(= a)selgei/as. The letter here read
was presumably addressed to one or more of the principal towns of Euboea, and its drift was probably to encourage anti-Athenian feelings and hopes.

§ 38-41 Philip's strictures are well deserved, and, though they may not be pleasant hearing, we must put up with what is unpleasant (38) and learn the lesson that wise policy aims at guiding events and not following them (39). Till now you have used your great resources like clumsy boxers, always guarding where the last blow fell instead of watching the next (40). Thus you allow Philip to direct all your movements. But now times are too critical for such dallying (41).

ou) mh\n a)lla\ here answers me/n, and is much more strongly adversative than de\ or me/ntoi. The use seems to have been originally elliptical; note that the ou) is not simply repeated by the following ou)x.
ta\ pra/gmata, ‘the actual course of events.’ The sense is, ‘if we can prevent things from happening by not mentioning them.’
h( tw=n lo/gwn xa/ris, ‘complaisance in language.’
a)naballome/nous, see on § 14.
mhde\ tou=to, ‘not even this simple lesson.’

ou)k a)kolouqei=n. The negative belongs grammatically to the governing dei=; the infinitive would require mh/. The construction is dei= tou\s...xrwme/nous ou)k a)kolouqei=n...a)ll'...e)/mprosqen ei)=nai...kai\ (dei=) tou\s bouleuome/nous (h(gei=sqai) tw=n pragma/twn, w(/sper ktl. It is also possible to supply a)ciou=n from a)ciw/seien, making the supplied h(gei=sqai depend on it (‘one ought to require counsellors to guide’): this however is not so suitable.
to\n strathgo/n: we might have expected a plural corresponding to tw=n strateuma/twn; but numbers are not infrequently interchanged in this way. The singular is here used with the universal force.

e)kei/nois refers to the subject (tou\s bouleuome/nous); it is preferred to sfi/sin or au)toi=s (1) for emphasis, (2) because the final clause is felt as dependent rather on dei= than on h(gei=sqai; preferred to tou/tois, because tau=ta is to follow.
ta\ sumba/nta diw/kein, ‘to keep chasing events,’ i.e. to mould their policy according to the dictation of each event as it occurs.
ei)s de/on ti. Cf. § 14.

ou)de\n a)polei/pete ... polemei=n , lit. ‘you leave out nothing so as to carry on war’; so ‘you conduct your warfare exactly as barbarians box.’ Cf. Plato Phaedo 69 D w(=n dh\ kai\ e)gw\...ou)de\n a)pe/lipon...
gene/sqai (not quite a certain example), Thuc. VII.70 braxu\ ga\r a)pe/lipon cunamfo/terai diako/siai gene/sqai.

th=s plhgh=s e)/xetai, ‘clings to the blow,’ i.e. ‘keeps his hands where the last blow fell.’ Note that in Attic prose plhgh\ is the substantive, as e)plh/ghn is the passive aorist and e)pa/taca the active aorist regularly used to correspond to the present tu/ptw in the sense of ‘to strike’ or ‘to wound.’
ka)/n . kai\ is here the simple copula.

e)kei=se used pregnantly with ei)si/n; ‘go thither and are there’ (i.e. where the second blow has fallen): cf. a line quoted by Plutarch de garrulitate 513 E o(/pou tis a)lgei=, kei=se kai\ th\n xei=r' e)/xei.

proba/llesqai, ‘to put before oneself for one's defence’: understand ta\s xei=ras. So also in battle, with similar ellipse of th\n a)spi/da. The infinitive after oi)=da or e)pi/stamai meaning ‘to know how’ is regular.
*fi/lippon, sc. o)/nta.
sumparaqei=te, ‘you run about at his heels.’
strathgei=sqe, a bold exaggeration. The Athenians allow Philip to direct their movements as completely as if he were their own general.
pro\ tw=n pragma/twn is pleonastic, the sense being more fully given in the clause pri\n a)\n...pu/qhsqe. Note the alliteration.
au)th\n th\n a)kmh/n, ‘the very crisis.’ h(/kei, sc. tau=ta.
ou)ke/t' e)gxwrei=, ‘there is no longer room’ for such a weak policy.

§ 42-44 Perhaps Providence has made Philip so active in order to rouse you from your sloth (42). Is there not enough already to stir you? Are we to trust to luck and wait to be crushed (43)? Do not make difficulties. Active policy will find the way, but slackness is fatal (44).
mhde\n e)/pratten e)/ti, ‘he were meddling with no further projects.’
a)poxrh=n (with a)/n), oblique after dokei=, representing the imperfect indicative of the direct. The subject of a)poxrh=n is to be gathered from the protasis, ‘such a state of things.’
e)c w(=n, ‘though in consequence of it.’

w)flhko/tes is used in different senses with its two objects, (1) ‘to incur,’ (2) ‘to incur the reproach of.’ Both are fairly common. The periphrastic pluperfect indicates the lasting result of the action, ‘we should be saddled with.’
tini/, neuter.
tou= plei/onos, ‘more’ than he already has; not (as in ple/on e)/xein) more than his neighbours. Cf. Thuc. IV.17 a)ei\ tou= ple/onos e)lpi/di o)re/gontai.
a)pegnw/kate, ‘have abandoned hope,’ used absolutely as in Dem. 3. 33. It is also found with an object, ‘to despair of.’
qauma/zw with ei), ‘I wonder if,’ tends to acquire the meaning ‘I am surprised that,’ implying no doubt as to the fulfilment of the dependent clause.

a)lla\ mh\n k.t.e(. This sentence cannot be in place where it stands; if it is to fit into its place, it must mean ‘but this is clearly what we now have to fight against’—dh=lon o(/ti ki/nduno/s e)sti mh\ kakw=s pa/qwmen: and ou) sth/setai does not imply this with sufficient clearness. Any other interpretation however will break the connexion of the period; for in the next sentence tou=to must mean to\ paqei=n kakw=s u(po\ *fili/ppou. It seems best either to remove the sentence and place it at the beginning of the section (so Blass), or to read o(/ti tou=t' e)/stai for o(/ti g' ou) sth/setai. To suppose that tou=to in the next sentence means to\ kwlu/ein tin' au)to/n is to ignore the fact that tis is here indefinite only in form and really means Athens.
kena/s, ‘without men.’

para\ tou= dei=nos, either (1) ‘derived from so-and-so,’ i.e. based on the promises of some politician, like ta\s a)po\ tou= bh/matos e)lpi/das in § 45, or (2) brachylogically ‘hopes of assistance from so-and-so,’ e.g. from some Thracian or Persian potentate.
pa/nt' e)/xein, ‘that you have all that you need.’ Cf. Arist. Birds, 1543 h(/n g' h)\n su\ par' e)kei/nou parala/bh|s, pa/nt' e)/xeis.

me/rei ge/ tini. Either (1) ‘with a force consisting in part at least of citizen soldiers’ or (2) ‘with some part at least of our citizen army.’ The former is supported by the fact that the genitive has no article.
h)/reto/ tis, more graphic than the usual e)/roit' a)/n tis.
ta\ saqra/, ‘the weak spots.’ A similar thought appears in an expanded form in Dem. 2. 21.

ou)de/pot' ou)de\n mh\ ge/nhtai, simply a stronger form of ou) mh\ ge/nhtai/ pote/ ti, the sense being that of a strong denial in future time. In such cases either the ou) or the mh\ or both may be compounded, and the ou) (not the mh\) may be repeated for greater emphasis, as here, provided that the uncompounded ou) must not follow any of its compounds.

p.hi: A citizen force carries with it the star of Athens; but these paper armies do harm only to our allies.

div2.p: o(/poi ... a)\n ... sunapostalh=| must be taken together, oi=)mai being merely parenthetic.
to\ th=s tu/xhs, almost equivalent to h( tu/xh, as in § 12: do not supply eu)mene/s.
keno/n, ‘unsupported by any practical steps’: the phraseology of § 43 is intentionally echoed here.

bh/matos. When the e)kklhsi/a was assembled in the Pnyx, those who wished to speak did not simply rise in their places but made their way (parh=lqon) to the platform (bh=ma) reserved for speakers (cf. the tribune of the French Assembly).

a)posto/lous, governed through implication by teqna=si tw=| de/ei, which contains the sense of dedi/asi; cf. Dem. 19. 81 teqna/nai tw=| fo/bw| *qhbai/ous. Accusatives thus loosely governed are not uncommon.

p.hi: The general has no power; his mercenaries are not paid; we receive no trustworthy report of his actions; and what then can we expect?

div2.p: e(/n' a)/ndra, i.e. the general, despatched without troops.
fh=sai, ‘say “oh yes.”’ The ‘promises of Chares’ became a proverb.
a)pomi/sqwn, ‘without pay,’ here only in this sense. Elsewhere the word means ‘paid off,’ ‘discharged.’

r(a|di/ws, either with yeudo/menoi, ‘the orators who lightly spread false reports,’ or with e)nqa/d' w)=sin ‘can be in Athens without any trouble.’ For the latter, which is somewhat favoured by the rhythm, cf. § 32 pro\s au)th=| th=| xw/ra|...r(a|di/ws e)/stai.

o(/ ti a)
 tu/xhte, sc. yhfizo/menoi, ‘at haphazard.’ The personal construction is generally preferred. Cf. Thuc. III.43 pro\s o)rgh
 h(/ntin' a)
 tu/xhte e)/stin o(/te sfale/ntes, Phil. 3. 54.
kai\ is frequently placed, as here, immediately after an interrogative word, with a force which may best be given in English by throwing stress upon an auxiliary verb, ‘what must we expect?’

§ 47-50 You must establish a direct connexion with your troops by sending out citizens among them. At present your generals face death in the law-court more often than in the field (47). Meanwhile we repeat to one another the latest rumours about Philip's intentions (48). Now however ambitious his projects, he is not so mad as to reveal them to the greatest fools in Athens (49). Neglect such tales and bear in mind simply that he is our successful enemy, that our policy has failed, and that we must fight him at once or suffer for it (50).
a)podei/chte, ‘shew to be,’ here as often means little more than ‘make’; the object is tou\s au)tou\s and the following substantives are predicative.
oi)/kad' e)lqo/ntas, ‘after their return,’ with dikasta\s only.

eu)qunw=n, the regular examination to which Athenian magistrates had to submit at the end of their year of office. Charges brought in connexion with this examination were tried before a heliastic court, which might contain members of the army and would in any case be representative of the whole people.
ei)s tou=q' h(/kei. Cf. § 9 oi(= proelh/luq' a)selgei/as.

kri/netai is usually accompanied by the simple genitive: here peri\ is added to emphasise by repetition the contrast between kri/nesqai peri\ q. and a)gwni/sasqai peri\ q. Cases of such trials are those of Autocles and Cephisodotus (Dem. 23. 104, 153), Callisthenes and Chares (Aeschin. 2. 30, 71) and Leosthenes (Diod. XV. 95).
meta\ *lakedaimoni/wn must be taken with pra/ttein, ‘making arrangements with the L. for.’

ta\s politei/as, ‘the free states’ under constitutional government, especially in Arcadia, where they had been supported by Thebes in opposition to Sparta. As the rise of Thebes had brought about a rapprochement between Athens and Sparta, a report that Philip was assisting Sparta and trying to humiliate Thebes would be popular.

w(s pe/pomfen. Any construction other than the infinitive after fa/nai is very unusual. It is suggested that this departure from common usage is due to the hiatus which would be involved in pepomfe/nai w(s. Some prefer to leave out the first w(s and read pepomfe/nai. The exact bearing of this report, which seems to have had some truth in it, on the policy of Athens is not very clear.
e)n *)illurioi=s, so that as Philip has his hands full in the North, there can be no need for immediate action on the part of Athens.

pla/ttontes e(/kastos. When a plural subject is distributed by a singular in apposition to it, predicates may agree with either. Instead of continuing the construction (e.g. with oi( de\ o(\ a)\n e(/kastos tu/xh| fa/skousi) the orator breaks off abruptly and sums up the sense of the whole sentence in a single clause, inverting the construction (periio/ntes fasi\—pla/ttontes perierxo/meqa).
tw=n kwluso/ntwn. For the article cf. § 23 th\n...paratacome/nhn.
me/ntoi answers to the me\n of the preceding clause: me/ntoi may be substituted for de\ in most cases, and is regularly so substituted when the clause which it introduces begins with ou) or mh/.
a)posterei=, ‘is keeping us out of,’ the usual meaning.

eu(/rhtai, sc. praxqe/nta, taking a(/panta as the subject. It seems less desirable on grounds of sense to take a(/panta as the object and supply pra/cas. In either case the ellipse is so awkward that I am inclined to think that the participle has fallen out of the text.
e)n au)toi=s h(mi=n e)sti/, ‘depends on ourselves.’
o(/ti fau=la, sc. e)/stai.
Peroration (e)pi/logos). I have explained without shirking the policy which I am convinced is best, though I know that I may suffer for it. May your decision be guided aright.

o(/ ti a)\n mh\ ... w)= , ‘save in so far as I have been convinced that it would serve your best interests as well’ (as afford gratification). The primary form is employed, as often, in the subordinate clause, after the historic ei(lo/mhn. Here perhaps it is intended to imply that the speaker's conviction still holds.
ou)de\n u(posteila/menos, ‘without reserve.’ The metaphor is from shortening sail.

h(/dion ei)=xon, ‘I should have been better pleased.’ Elsewhere h(de/ws e)/xein is found with the dative or pro\s and the accusative (of a person). The reading is not quite certain. All MSS. except S give ei)=pon, to which the objection is that the imperfect would be more natural here than the aorist.

e)p' a)dh/lois ou)=si. For this use of e)pi\ with the dative of attendant circumstances or conditions (‘with the results to myself uncertain’) and a predicative adjective, cf. Dem. 21. 30 e)p' a)dh/lois me\n toi=s a)dikh/sousin, Soph. Ant. 556 a)ll' ou)k e)p) a)rrh/tois ge toi=s e)moi=s lo/gois. In the following clause e)pi\ has not quite the same force: e)pi\ tw=| pepei=sqai=‘on the strength of my conviction.’

Demosthenes is not perhaps thinking of any evil consequences more definite than unpopularity, but the fear of a grafh\ parano/mwn can never have been far from the mind of an Athenian who had to propose any measure likely to give offence.

§ 1-5 Introduction (prooi/mion). When we discuss Philip's violations of the peace, our verbal protests are quite justifiable, but they bring no practical results (1). The difficulty is that the more evidence we have of his wrongdoing, the harder it becomes to suggest a policy (2): because, whereas action is necessary, our politicians, through fear of unpopularity, shrink from advising active measures and take refuge in denunciations, while you, for all the correctness of your attitude towards right and wrong, are not ready to check the latter by active exertion (3). Naturally therefore your success is verbal, Philip's practical. You can prove your pleas against him easily enough (4). But if we are to retrieve our losses we must change our course and prefer a salutary to a popular policy (5).

pra/ttei kai\ bia/zetai. The two verbs are best taken as alternative descriptions of the same course of action (such as are frequently coupled by kai\)—‘is doing, yes, violently doing.’ Render ‘about Philip's lawlessly aggressive policy.’ Other solutions are (1) to supply pra/ttein with bia/zetai, ‘forcibly endeavours to effect,’ and (2) to suppose the two verbs to be contrasted, ‘Philip's policy whether of intrigue or of violence.’
filanqrw/pous, ‘generous,’ i.e. towards the rest of Greece.
fainome/nous, sc. o)/ntas, ‘are clearly.’
dokou=ntas, ‘are thought,’ a common special significance of the word.

w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n, ‘almost,’ ‘practically,’ used, as it regularly is, to modify a universal statement—most frequently with pa=s and ou)dei/s. Distinguish tw=n deo/ntwn (a(\ dei= gi/gnesqai) here from ta\ de/onta (a(\ dei= le/gesqai) above, each taking its colour from the controlling verb.
w(=n ei(/neka for e)kei/nwn (with ou)de\n) w(=n ei(/neka.
ei)s tou=to, here without a genitive, as in Phil. III. 1. See on Phil. I. 9 and 37.
to\ with sumbouleu=sai. ti/ is direct interrogative used for indirect, as in 1. 36.
xalepw/teron, sc. e)sti\n, or ei)=nai, after w(/ste.
e)/rgw| kai\ pra/cesi. Cf. Dem. 8. 73 dei= d' e)/rgwn th=| po/lei kai\ pra/cew/s tinos. So far as the two words can be distinguished, e)/rgon emphasises reality, pra=cis activity.
oi( pario/ntes, sc. e)pi\ to\ bh=ma w(/ste le/gein e)n tw=| dh/mw|.

tou/twn, gen. after a)fe/stamen, further expanded by the infinitives. The slight looseness of construction is made easier by the fact that a)fi/stasqai belongs to a class of verbs (implying abstention and the like) after which an infinitive is commonly used.

pro\s u(ma=s. With words denoting friendly feeling or the reverse pro\s may be used with the accusative not only, as seems natural to us, of the object, but also, as here, of the subject. Cf. Thuc. V.105 th=s pro\s to\ qei=on eu)menei/as (the favour of heaven).

oi)=a poiei= is either (1) object of diecerxo/meqa (‘what sort of things he does, and how monstrous they are’), or (2) subject of deina/ (e)sti) (‘how monstrous are the kind of things he does’), or (3) object of diec. used anticipatorily. The third view seems best and is supported by Dem. 18. 41 ta\...pa/qh...dieciw\n w(s oi)ktra/. In any case toiau=ta is direct object of diec.
kaqh/menoi, sc. e)n th=| e)kklhsi/a|.
w(s me\n a)\n ei)/poite, a relative clause, similar in character to an object-clause containing o(/pws and a future indicative; lit. ‘as to the way in which you might speak.’
e)f' w(=n e)sti, ‘his enterprises’: e)pi\=‘engaged upon,’ a use somewhat similar to that in Phil. 1. 7.
ei)ko/s, either ‘reasonable, equitable’ or ‘probable, natural.’ The former is to be preferred, as the latter, especially with the addition of i)/sws, involves an anticlimax.
e)n oi(=s. The explanation of the pra=gma is introduced, as such explanations not infrequently are, without a conjunction.
kai\ nu=n, ‘now, as heretofore.’
skopei=n, which implies the pursuit of an aim, is followed by an object-clause introduced by o(/pws and containing three futures indicative; the construction is normal.
porrwte/rw, ‘further,’ i.e. ‘into a worse plight.’
pa/nta, ‘the whole situation.’
e)pisth/setai, ‘rise up to threaten us,’ as in Dem. 18. 176 to\n e)festhko/ta ki/ndunon th=| po/lei.
me/geqos duna/mews, equivalent to tosau/th du/namis.
§ 6-28 Discussion (a)po/deicis) including (1) sketch of the situation (dih/ghsis) §§ 6—27, (2) proposals (pro/qesis) most of which is not included in the extant text, § 28.

p.hi: In case any of you do not see a menace to Athens in Philip's rise, pray hear my reasoning, so that you may decide whether to believe me or my opponents.

div2.p: qarrei=, ‘is not afraid’; the verb has frequently no distinctly positive meaning: indeed it is so far treated as the contradictory of fobei=sqai that it is used with an accusative (‘to have no fear of’).
pa/ntwn o(moi/ws, ‘all alike,’ whether willing or unwilling to hear me favourably.
dia\ braxe/wn, elsewhere used by Demosthenes with verbs of speaking (not of listening), so that we should here supply the participle of such a verb (le/gontos or legome/nous).

di) ou(\s is not to be very clearly distinguished here from di) w(=n, the change being due, as it seems, merely to love of variety. As a rule the accusative is used of the cause (especially the final cause) and the genitive of the means.
pare/sthke, ‘it has occurred to me,’ construed as in Dem. 3. 1 ou)xi\ tau)ta\ pari/statai/ moi gignw/skein. Cf. parasth=sai in Phil. I. 17.

prosqh=sqe, ‘you may attach yourselves,’ as in § 12. It is not of course the orator's purpose that his hearers should favour his opponents; but the i(/na-clauses may be made to depend on a)kou=sai rather than on dehqh=nai bou/lomai, so that the purpose will be that of the listeners. There is a close parallel in Phil. III. 20. Some editors however prefer to read prosqh/sesqe with S, which makes the sentence run less smoothly.

§ 7-12 After the peace Philip's first act was to make himself master of Thermopylae and Phocis. These advantages he employed for the benefit of Thebes, not of Athens, because he was pursuing his own ends (7) and knew that Athens would never basely betray the interests of Greece to him (8), whereas Thebes would readily aid him to secure her own profit. With the same policy he is now favouring Argos and the Messenians. This is a compliment to you (9); for it shews that Philip does not believe that any consideration would bribe you to surrender the welfare of Greece. His belief in your honour and in the baseness of Argos and Thebes is justified by history (10).
In the Persian Wars you refused to treat with the invaders, and earned great glory by the heroism of your resistance, while Thebes joined the Persians and Argos offered no opposition (11). So Philip assists them instead of you because his aims are such as you could not support. He can have no other reason (12).
ti/nwn, neuter; direct question for indirect, depending, by a slight laxity, on logi/zomai. See Introd. § 13.
sumfe/rei, present, though the main clause is past, because the interests of Thebes are still served by Philip's past choice of a policy.
pro/s, ‘with an eye to,’ ‘by the standard of,’ with e)ceta/zwn, ‘testing.’
h)/qesi, abstract for concrete, ‘men of such character’; or it may be taken with po/lei as e(\n dia\ duoi=n.
e)ndei/caito, ‘make a display of’ and so ‘hold out as a lure’: with poih/seien, it contrasts promise with performance: ‘no service that he could promise or perform would be so powerful.’
u(f' ou(= for w(/sq' u(p) e)kei/nou: the simple relative is fairly often used to introduce consecutive clauses after tosou=tos and toiou=tos.

pro/oisqe. Supply a)\n from the main clause. The spelling and accentuation of the word are rather uncertain. As the tense-stem is e( and the tense is non-thematic the optative should be formed with i, e(-i-mhn (-sqe), which would give proei=sqe or pro/eisqe. If the spelling in the text is correct for Demosthenes we must suppose that it is due to the insertion of the thematic vowel o on the analogy of thematic tenses. This would give e(-o-i-mhn, contracting into oi)/mhn: in this case the accent should remain on the contracted syllable—prooi=sqe; but the accent also may have been changed by false analogy.
th\n ... pra/gmati . For the order see on Phil. I. 17. tw=| pra/gmati goes closely with prosou=san.

w(/sper a)/n, sc. e)nantiwqei=te. Where w(s or w(/sper is followed by ei), a(\n is frequently used in this way with ellipse of an optative, so frequently indeed that the ellipse is probably quite unconscious.

o(/per sune/bh, ‘as indeed happened.’ The Thebans were of course in alliance with Philip when he entered Phocis as general of the Amphictyonic League; but as the orator seems here to refer to later events, it would seem that he is exaggerating (in so far as these words apply to sustrateu/sein).
tw=n e(autoi=s gignome/nwn, ‘what accrued to them,’ ‘the profits they were receiving’ or ‘were to receive.’

ou)x o(/pws, ‘not only not,’ ‘far from.’ It is generally supposed that this idiom has arisen, like ou)x o(/ti, by the ellipse of a verb of saying in the indicative—‘I do not say how’ (or, with o(/ti, ‘that’), mh\ o(/ti with a similar sense having arisen by the ellipse of a similar verb in the imperative. Thus the meaning would be ‘not to say,’ ‘not to speak of,’ and so ‘not only,’ or ‘not only not.’ There is no ellipse of a negative as there is in the Latin use of non modo for non modo non. The idiom is stereotyped and has ceased to affect the syntax of the verbs.
tau)/q' u(peilhfw/s, ‘with the same conception (of their character) in his mind.’

The Messenians, since the restoration of their independence after Leuctra, and the Argives, since the skutalismo\s of their oligarchs about the same time, had been distinctly anti-Lacedaemonian. In supporting them therefore Philip was acting against the interests of Sparta, with whom Athens was now on friendly terms.

kaq' u(mw=n, ‘passed upon you,’ not infrequently of complimentary language though much commoner of the reverse. The origin of this use of kata\ seems to be metaphorical, epithets good or bad being conceived as poured over or showered upon the recipient.

e)k tou/twn, ‘as the result of,’ and so ‘as is shewn by these actions’ on Philip's part. ke/krisqe is an example of Greek preference for the personal construction. We should rather use the impersonal— ‘a verdict has been given that you would not.’
a)\n ... proe/sqai represents a)\n with the optative of the oratio recta, as regularly.
