ke/rdous, genitive of price. It is not easy to say why the negatives are here forms containing mh\ rather than ou). The rule is that the negative in oratio obliqua is the same as it would be in recta (here ou)k a)\n pro/oisqe), unless the governing verb has a construction which requires mh/. But mh\ is sometimes used where there is a notion of insistence upon a statement (examples in Goodwin, M. and T. § 685, where another explanation is offered).
ei)s, indistinguishable from pro\s in this connexion: see on § 3.
kata/, equivalent to peri/, used for variety.
w(s e(te/rws. See on w(s a)lhqw=s, Phil. I. 27.
ei)s ta\ paro/nta. After o(ra=n, ei)s conveys the idea of attention on the gazer's part more than does the simple accusative.
eu(ri/skei, i.e. in records.

e)co/n. It is worth noting that the accusative absolute of such
impersonal participles has frequently a concessive force; cf. § 3 de/on.
w(/ste, ‘on condition that’ (Latin ita ut). Cf. Dem. 21. 3 xrh/mata labei=n w(/ste mh\ kathgorei=n.
*ale/candros, Alexander the Philhellene: see Introd. § 2. The use of the plural in tou/twn is rather contemptuous; it is slightly awkward as followed closely by tou/twn neuter.

e)klipei=n, before Salamis and Plataea in 480 and 479 B.C. The language of Demosthenes implies that Alexander was at Athens before Salamis, whereas in reality his visit took place shortly before Plataea.
le/gein, ‘to be telling of’; the present suggests the idea of harping on the theme, an implication which is absent in the following ei)pei=n.
dikai/ws, placed at the end of its clause (like ei)ko/tws, Phil. I. 24) where an explanation follows.
h)\ w(s, more commonly h)\ w(/ste followed by the infinitive, answers to our use of ‘too.’ The w(s is relative; lit. ‘than as one would tell.’
tou\s me/n, the Thebans, who fought on the Persian side at Plataea.
i)di/a|, with lusitelou=n. It would naturally come between the article and the participle, but is placed first for emphasis and to avoid hiatus.
ei) ... e(/loito , oblique representing e)a\n e(/lhtai (or rather e(/lwmai) of the oratio recta.
sunergou\s carries a sinister suggestion, ‘accomplices,’ as contrasted with fi/lous.
to/te, when the peace was concluded. Supply a past tense from the present ai(rei=tai.

dh\ adds a suggestion of irony, like dh/pou. The collocation ou) ga\r dh\ is fairly common and is often followed as here by ge, which throws into relief the important word of the sentence. We find this use when an explanation is followed and supported by the refutation of other possible explanations.
eu(/rhken, ‘has discovered’; both this word and tina suggest that the idea of an inland empire for Philip is fanciful and far-fetched.

e)pi\ th=| qala/tth|, ‘on the sea-coast.’ Sandys rightly points out that the phrase could not mean ‘on the sea’ (in the sense of ‘a maritime empire’); but he is wrong, I think, in arguing that
we must supply gh=s or xw/ras rather than a)rxh=s with th=s, though the ellipse of such a word is very common. a)fe/sthken does not imply that Philip already possessed such an empire: render, ‘has renounced (the idea of).’ Cf. § 3 a)fe/stamen.
e)f' ai(=s, ‘on the strength of which.’ It is fair to remember that the promises were made not by Philip but by his partisans at Athens.

p.hi: I may be told that his preference for Thebes is based on honourable motives. This is refuted by the inconsistency of his actions.

div2.p: a)lla\ nh\ *di/a, a regular formula (like Cicero's at enim) for introducing an argument supposed to be put forward by an adversary.

w(s pa/nta tau=t' ei)dw/s, ‘pretending knowledge of all these matters,’ i.e. of Philip's motives. It is best thus to take ei)dw\s as agreeing with tis. Some would make it agree with the subject of e)/pracen (Philip), making w(s equivalent to o(/ti, while pa/nta tau=ta will be the knowledge attributed to Philip in §§ 11, 12: but with a)lla\ nh\ *di/a the objection is normally in oratio recta.
w(=n for tou/twn (e(/neka) a(/.
tw=| a)ciou=n, causal dative. tou\s *qhbai/ous is subject.
kai/, with mo/non, giving a concessive force—‘this plea, though it be the only one,’ ‘this plea, even if no other’; so ‘this above all others.’

to/te, on the conclusion of the peace. The argument is this:— Philip is now claiming liberty for the Messenians (over whom Sparta has exercised dominion for centuries); his justification can only be the principle that every distinct nationality ought to enjoy independence. But he acted contrary to this principle in the case of O. and C. (though their independence had been maintained until after Leuctra, and they had therefore a much stronger case than the Messenians). The construction of the last words is skh/yaito pepoihke/nai (sc. tau=ta) tw=| nomi/zein (causal) tau=ta di/kaia ei)=nai.

§ 14-16 I may be told that his action was forced upon him. It is said similarly that his intention is to mistrust Thebes (14). But whatever his intention, his present action is to help Argos and Messene. When he thus injures Sparta, the foe of Thebes, can we believe in his kindly intentions towards Phocis (15)? No. Considering his actions, it is clear that his policy is to support Thebes and weaken Athens (16).

e)n me/sw|, with the Thebans in front and the Thessalians in his rear at Thermopylae. The Thessalian cavalry, 3000 strong even on a peace footing, were famous. This argument was put forward later by Aeschines (Aesch. 2. 140).
kalw=s, ironically, ‘a capital plea!’
u(po/ptws e)/xein, used actively, as in Dem. 19. 132 e)/xein...u(po/ptws pro\s to\n *fi/lippon.

*)ela/teian, a town of great strategical importance, commanding the entrances to Phocis and Boeotia from the North. Philip carried out this ‘intention’ in 339, but not in the spirit here suggested by his apologists.
mellh/sei, ‘will go on intending,’ i.e. he will never carry out the intention.

sullamba/nein, ‘to assist,’ is Weil's conjecture, confirmed by a scholiast's note on Aristoph. Ach. 206. S has sumba/llein which some editors attempt unsuccessfully to defend; it may be retained in the sense of ‘to embroil’ if with Cobet we omit e)pi/, but the sense is not quite satisfactory, and the use of the word is questionable Attic.
tou\s me\n o)/ntas e)xqrou/s, ‘the existing foes,’ as contrasted with the Phocians. The clinching point is brought out more sharply by the absence of a conjunction.
sw/|zei. This line of policy is indicated in the *)ela/teian teixiei= of § 14.
kai\ ti/s, a scornful question. Such is frequently the drift of a question introduced by kai/.
a)/n, with e)nantiou=sqai, oblique for a)\n with the imperfect indicative, ‘that he would be opposing,’ as he is.
ta) pra=ta, the subjection of Orchomenus and Coronea to Thebes.
a)pegi/gnwsken, ‘were throwing over,’ transitive, as in Dem. 3. 33 a)pogno/ntas (sc. au)ta/).
ka)kei=na=kai\ ta\ prw=ta.

e)k pa/ntwn, parallel to a)f' w(=n nu=n poiei= as sunta/ttwn is to poih/sas. So e)k pa/ntwn must be taken with dh=lo/s e)sti. pa/nq' a(\ is Foertsch's excellent conjecture for the pa/nta of S, which affords a very awkward sentence. Other MSS. read o(/ti pa/nta, but with an ugly hiatus and a clumsy structure.

§ 17-19 Philip is really forced to side with our enemies. For (a) his great object is empire, and you are therefore his obvious
rivals, and (b) he has already had to incur your enmity in the pursuit of his aim (17). Knowing that you are aware of his designs and must therefore detest him, he is eager to strike before you can strike him (18). Hence his restless activity and his friendly attitude towards such Greeks as he considers will seek their own advantage and fail to foresee his ultimate purposes. Yet these purposes are easy to guess. let me repeat to you the warmng which I gave to the Messenians and Argives (19).
tro/pon tina/, ‘in a way.’ Philip is driven to this policy, but not in the sense of e)bia/sqh in § 14.
tou/tou, ‘in this ambition,’ with a)ntagwnista/s. Notice the asyndeton in enumerating the points of the calculation.
oi(=s, object of e)/xei, attracted into the case of its antecedent tou/tois.

a)
 belongs to the infinitive, as in § 16. There is some ambiguity here: proei=to may be either optative or indicative of the aorist or pluperfect indicative. There is no ground for taking the last view, but each of the others is fairly reasonable. If proei=to is indicative, a)
...me/nein represents a)
...e)/menon of the recta—‘if I had abandoned A. and P. (at the time of the peace) I could not now so much as remain at home in security.’ If optative (see on § 8) a)
...me/nein represents a)
...me/noimi—‘if I were to abandon A. and P., I should not, etc.’ I prefer the last view on the ground that the whole passage is concerned with Philip's present situation, in view of present possibilities. (Notice the somewhat emphatic nu=n ge dh\ at the beginning of this section, and the present tenses which surround our passage.) For the same reason I accept Cobet's h(gei=tai for the MS. reading h(gei=to (S) or h(goi=to. If h(gei=to is retained it must mean ‘he thought’ at the time of the Peace; in that case the proei=to must be taken as optative, and me/nein as representing me/noimi.

au(to\n...e)pibouleu/onta. The normal construction would be au)to\s e)pibouleu/wn, as the subject is identical with that of oi)=de; but the accusative of the reflexive is sometimes preferred. The reason here seems to be the symmetry of the two accusatives.
eu)= fronei=n, ‘to be sensible,’ rather than ‘loyal’ to Greece.
poih/sas, sc. ti, the same ‘something’ as in the euphemistic pei/sesqai/ ti, i.e. some harm. poiei=n and pa/sxein frequently correspond as active and passive.
pro/teros, redundant after fqa/sh|; cf. Phil. I. 14 mh\ pro/teron prolamba/nete.

e)fe/sthken, sc. toi=s pra/gmasi, ‘he is on the alert,’ ‘he is ever on the spot’; literally the word is used of standing beside a person or thing in readiness to act at a moment's notice: compare the English sailor's ‘stand by.’
e)pi\ th=| po/lei, ‘to threaten Athens.’
tou/tois (the Thebans) must be construed with tau)ta/.
ta\ paro/nt' a)gaph/sein, ‘will embrace the profit of the moment.’
skaio/thta, in allusion especially to the Thebans, whose stupidity was proverbial.
kai\ metri/ws, with swfronou=si, ‘men endowed even moderately with sober sense.’
sune/bh, a touch of modesty. The allusion is to the proceedings of the envoys despatched to the Peloponnesus in 344 on Demosthenes' advice to counteract the designs of Philip.

§ 20-22 “Formerly,” said I, “Philip made concessions to Olynthus, and risked your hostility for her benefit. Could she then have any idea of what was to come (20)? But after brief prosperity she lost all through his action. So perilous for a free state is the friendship of a despot (21). Formerly Philip expelled despots from Thessaly and gave the Thessalians possessions and privileges. Could they then suppose that he would deprive them of liberty and property? But he has done so (22).”

pw=s ga\r oi)/esqe. pw=s is frequently used with the second person (sing. or plur.) of a verb of thinking followed in many cases by an adverb, with a sense corresponding roughly to that of the English ‘you can't think how’: the verb of thinking may be treated either as the principal verb, as here, or as parenthetic. Cf. Dem. 1. 24 pw=s a)\n au)to\n oi)/esq' e(toi/mws...e)lqei=n; ‘you can guess how readily,’ Aristoph. Ach. 24 w)stiou=ntai pw=s dokei=s, ‘you can't think how they'll jostle,’ Frogs 54 e)pa/tace pw=s oi)/ei sfo/dra, ‘struck me with—oh, such a pang!’ We may guess that originally the second adverb was the reply to the question pw=s.
a)kou/ein is the infinitive of the imperfect, ei)...le/goi being a general condition in past time: so prosdoka=n below.

*)anqemou=nta, a town whose exact position is not known. It was presumably near the frontier between Macedonia and the Chalcidian territories. It seems to have belonged to Macedonia since the 6th century (Thuc. II.99, 100), so that a)ntepoiou=nto is rather an understatement of the case. Anthemus was handed over to Olynthus in 357, Potidaea, ‘the key of the peninsula of Pallene,’ in 356. See Introd. §§ 5, 6, 11.
th\n xw/ran, as the town itself was destroyed.
karpou=sqai, infin. of purpose, common after verbs of giving.
le/gontos a)\n ... pisteu=sai , oblique, representing le/gontos (=ei) e)/legen) a)\n e)pi/steusan.
th\n a)llotri/an, with ellipse of gh=n, as in th=s au(tw=n. Potidaea is meant.
polu/n, sc. xro/non. Olynthus had been completely destroyed; but Demosthenes avoids the evil omen of saying ‘for ever.’
e)kpeso/ntes. This verb serves as passive to e)kba/llein.

prodoqe/ntes, which is a more shameful and miserable fate than subjugation by straightforward warfare. The fall of Olynthus was largely due to treachery. Cf. Phil. 3. 56, 66 and Dem. 8. 40. praqe/ntes seems to be used almost literally of Euthycrates, of whom Hyperides says (frag. 80) timhth\s e)ge/neto tw=n ai)xmalw/twn.
au(=tai. For the order cf. Phil. 1. 17.

ti/ de/, as frequently, with a more or less unconscious ellipse, in introducing a fresh subject. To avoid attempting to define the ellipse, we may render ‘What of the T.?’ or ‘Again, as to the T.’ Cf. Lat. quid uero?, quid autem?

tou\s tura/nnous, Lycophron and Peitholaus of Pherae, expelled in 352; at the same time Philip made himself master of the Magnesian district. This he handed over to the Thessalians in 346, together with Nicaea, which he had just wrested from the Phocians. The latter was a Locrian town, of some importance as commanding the southern approach to Thermopylae.

dekadarxi/an, ‘decemvirate.’ This is a much discussed term. There is no authority elsewhere for the belief that Philip ever established a single central government for Thessaly, though it is known that he set up four distinct provincial governments (tetrarxi/ai), and it seems clear that in general his policy was to divide rather than to centralise power in Thessaly. Of the many explanations which have been suggested perhaps the best is that Demosthenes intentionally used the wrong word in speaking to Messenians who would remember the oligarchical decarchies set up by Lysander.
th\n pulai/an, the right of presiding at Amphictyonic assemblies, of which the Thessalians had been deprived by the Phocians.
proso/dous, presumably the harbour and market dues mentioned in Dem. 1. 22.
ou)k e)/sti tau=ta, i.e. they could never have suspected it. Some, less naturally, take the words as a rhetorically feigned interruption from the audience—‘“Impossible!” you say.’

§ 23-25 “Just so,” I went on, “Philip is offering lures to you. See that he does not deceive you. Though there are many expensive material inventions for the defence of cities (23), there is one moral safeguard within the reach of all sensible men, beneficial especially to free states in dealing with despots. I mean mistrust. Cling to it and you are safe (24). Philip's very title makes him the foe of all who seek freedom. Take care lest in seeking peace you find a tyrant” (25).

qewrei=te, generally taken as indicative, but we should expect a word more distinctly implying satisfaction. Cobet felt this so strongly that he wished to read h(de/ws o(ra=te. It is possible that qewrei=te is imperative, ‘look on, if you like (but do not be moved).’
a)peu/xesqe, imperative, always, like Lat. deprecari, of praying for a negative issue.
koino/n, antithetic to dapa/nhs, as fu/sis to xeiropoi/hta.
fulakth/rion, predicative.
plh/qesin, ‘democratic communities.’
tau/ths. The repetition of the same word at the beginning of short sentences with asyndeton is a regular rhetorical device for emphasis.
ou)de\n mh\ deino/n, equivalent to ou) mh\ deino/n ti. Cf. Phil. 1. 44.
kai\ ta\s proshgori/as, ‘even his titles,’ i.e. those mentioned in the following words.
despo/thn, a very invidious word, being the correlative of dou=los; Lat. dominus.
eu(/rhte. The subjunctive with o(/pws in object-clauses after verbs of taking measures or precautions is much rarer than the future indicative. There are however ten examples in Demosthenes.

§ 26-27 Though they often listened with approval to these arguments, it seems likely that Philip's professions will beguile them after all (26). Well, they are but Peloponnesians. But it is only too likely that you Athenians, who ought to know better, will through your anxiety for present comfort come terribly to grief (27).
qorubou=ntes, participle of the imperfect. The words kai\... le/getai are parenthetic or inserted dia\ me/sou, and lo/gous is governed by a)kou/santes.
u(/steron. It would appear from these words that Demosthenes left Messenia before the rest of the envoys.
w(s e)/oiken, to be taken with what follows, ‘as it seems’ from their present attitude.
a)posxh/sontai, ‘refrain from,’ i.e. resist the temptation of.

ou) tou=to, emphatic and closely connected, ‘it is not this which is so strange.’ tou=to is explained by the ei) clause. The beginning of the sentence suggests that it is intended to proceed with a second member parallel to the first (e.g. a)ll' a)/topon e)kei=no, ei) u(mei=s k.t.e(.); but by breaking off and making the second part independent a more striking effect is obtained.

peristoixi/zesqe, a metaphor from snaring game. Another reading, periteixi/zesqe, has almost equally good MS. support, but does not give such good sense, as peritei/xisis is hardly a process which can go on without the victim's notice.

e)k tou= mhde\n h)/dh poih=sai, ‘through your avoidance of prompt action.’ The original reading of S was w(/ste for e)k tou=, but the w(/ste of ‘condition’ is incompatible with the unconsciousness implied in lh/sete.
As to what we should do, we had best reserve discussion till we are alone; but I have a suggestion to make now as to what we should say in reply to the envoys.
kaq' u(ma=s au)tou/s, ‘by yourselves,’ whereas it appears that certain foreign envoys were present in the Ecclesia during this discussion.
a)pokrina/menoi, the conditional participle, serving as protasis, equivalent to ei) a)pokri/naisqe.

It seems most probable that after this sentence Demosthenes read a draft reply or replies which he had prepared. See Introd. § 14. Others prefer to suppose that the draft was read at the end of the speech.

§ 28-37 A passage not very closely connected with the preceding part of the speech. The orator takes occasion to remind his audience who was really responsible for the Peace and the consequent misfortunes of Athens.

§ 28-30 You ought to have summoned to appear before you the men whose promises induced you to make the peace (28) (for our action was really due to their representations), and those who, as you remember, flouted me when on our return from the second embassy I endeavoured to warn you, and who made much of Philip's friendly intentions (29, 30).
h)=n ... di/kaion , where we should say ‘it would have been right.’ The imperfect, as frequently in the case of verbs implying duty and the like, implies that the act was not done.
tou\s e)negko/ntas, especially Aristodemus, Ctesiphon, and Neoptolemus.
kalei=n, so that they might be forced to admit their responsibility for such promises, and for their action in general.
oi)=d' o(/ti, used in parenthesis, has become a stereotyped phrase, with the value of an adverb, like dh=lon o(/ti.
tou/twn, Philip's present course of action.
kalei=n, sc. h)=n di/kaion.

tou/s, to be taken with le/gontas. The order of the words shews that the intervening temporal clause modifies the participle. The reference is to the pro-Macedonian orators (e.g. Aeschines and Philocrates); cf. Dem. 19. 45. It was usual in deliberative speeches not to mention opponents by name.
th=s e)pi\ tou\s o(/rkous, ‘the one sent to administer the oaths’ (to Philip). See Introd. §§ 12, 13.
prou)/legon kai\ diemarturo/mhn, ‘was warning you with solemn protestations.’
ou)k ei)/wn, ‘was bidding you not.’ With this verb ou) commonly coalesces so as to form a single conception—ou)k e)w==I forbid.
u(/dwr pi/nwn. The Assembly seems to have relished this joke; see Dem. 19. 45.
eu)/caisq' a)\n does not depend for its form on the protasis a)\n pare/lqh|, but means ‘what you would pray for’ (if you were to pray for all that you most wanted). pare/lqh|, sc. para\ ta\s *pu/las.
teixiei=. Thespiae and Plataeae had always stoutly resisted Theban supremacy over Boeotia and been friendly to Athens. Thebes had destroyed both towns in 372 B.C.

*xerro/nhson, i.e. the isthmus connecting it with the Thracian mainland. The object would be to protect the Athenian settlers against Thracian inroads. With this purpose a wall had been built from Cardia to Pactye by Miltiades, and subsequently restored by Pericles and again by Dercyllidas.
*eu)/boian. The island had been somewhat disturbed since Phocion's victory at Tamynae, though it was only after the date of this speech that Philip succeeded in gaining a firm footing there.

*)wrwpo/n, a town on the frontiers on Attica and Boeotia, which had long been a bone of contention between Athens and Thebes. It had now been in Theban hands since 366 B.C. With the whole passage compare Dem. 5. 10.

§ 31-34 Worst of all, you were led to agree that Philip's descendants should be included in the peace. Now my object in suggesting that these men should be summoned here (31) is not to provoke a squabble, from which they would get more advantage than I, nor to prolong idle speech (32). But as I foresee that a time may soon come when Philip's policy can no longer be ignored (33), I fear, as the ambassadors preserve discreet silence, lest you may then be angry with those politicians who endeavour to avert the results of their action, for some people vent their displeasure on the handiest victim, instead of on the guilty (34).
ai)/sxiston, best taken as accusative in apposition to the object of e)yhfi/sasqe.
pro\s ta\s e)lpi/das, ‘in view of the hopes’ inspired by Aeschines and others.
Philip's descendants were included by the resolution of Philocrates, carried at the second meeting of the Ecclesia. See Introd. § 12.
u(ph/xqhte, ‘you were beguiled.’ The u(po\ suggests stealthy action.
dei=n, infinitive of the imperfect, representing e)/dei (equivalent to di/kaion h)=n of § 28) in the oratio recta.
e)mpesw/n, ‘involving myself in.’ By loidori/an the orator probably means ‘mutual abuse,’ rather than merely ‘abuse of my opponents.’

lo/gon ... poih/sw , a somewhat odd phrase, which has been variously interpreted. The difficulty lies in the unusual combination of two common words of rather indeterminate significance. Literally the words mean ‘not that I may involve myself in recriminations and make speaking for myself on an equal footing’ (with my adversaries); but the exact meaning of ‘to make speaking’ is far from certain. The chief interpretations which have been offered are (1) ‘I may cause myself to obtain a hearing’ (lo/gon poiei=n=dicendi copiam facere in Dem. 23. 81), (2) ‘I may make a speech,’ elsewhere lo/gon poih/swmai (it is suggested that the active with the reflexive may be used for the middle in order to secure the balance of the two datives), (3) ‘I may get myself talked about,’ (4) ‘I may make something to talk about,’ (5) ‘I may manufacture talk,’ i.e. talk for the mere sake of talking, (6) taking e)c i)/sou as equivalent to a predicative adjective, ‘I may cause my speaking to be on a merely equal footing,’ i.e. bring my speaking down to a
level on which it will have no greater claim upon your respect than that of my adversaries. On the whole I prefer (1). The general sense will be ‘my object is not to involve myself in recriminations and so, while I obtain before you no more favourable hearing than my adversaries, to afford a pretext, etc.’

e)c a)rxh=s is to be taken with proskrou/sasin, kai\ nu=n (‘now also,’ further strengthened by pa/lin) with para/sxw. The pro-Macedonians would seize the opportunity to suggest that their service in renewing opposition to Demosthenes merited some recompense.
w(s a)/llws. See on Phil. 1. 27 w(s a)lhqw=s. Many MSS. give th\n a)/llws, which is an elliptical adverbial phrase (like th\n taxi/sthn) found in Dem. 3. 21.

Instead of expressing his real object by another i(/na-clause the speaker puts it independently with some amplification. The object is to forestall the danger which he mentions in the first sentence of § 34.
ta\ nuni/, an adverbial phrase, as frequently.

ou)xi\ bouloi/mhn a)\n, ‘I should wish not to prove a true prophet. The negative, though belonging logically to the infinitive (which would require mh/), is associated with the governing verb. Often similarly with fhmi/ and oi)=mai.
tou=to, i.e. to\ lupei=n u(ma=s ta\ u(po\ *fili/ppou pratto/mena.
a)melei=n. The substantive e)cousi/a is normally followed by a genitive (here tou= a)melei=n), but when accompanied by a verb may take the simple infinitive, like e)cei=nai.
tau=ta, i.e. Philip's intrigues.
e)f' u(ma=s, ‘directed against you.’

e)f' oi(=s. The construction is—sesiwphko/twn (transitive, ‘maintain silence about’) (e)kei=na) e)f' oi(=s dedwrodokhko/tes suni/sasin au(toi=s, ‘the services on the strength of which (or the conditions on which) they have, as they are conscious, accepted bribes.’ Some interpreters, not so well, take e)f' oi)=s as equivalent to e)p' e)kei/nois a(\— ‘maintain silence on (the conditions attached to) the bribes which they have taken’: but Philip paid his supporters for speech rather than for silence.
w(s ta\ polla/, ‘generally’: the commoner phrase is w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/.
u(po\ xei=ra, ‘under their hands,’ and so ‘within their reach.’ Take ma/lista with u(po\ xei=ra.

§ 35-37 So before the storm breaks I wish to make you realise
who was responsible for the loss of Thermopylae and the destruction of the Phocians, events which have given Philip command of the approach to southern Greece, so that you have now to consider home defence rather than foreign policy (35). For if you had not then been beguiled, Philip could never have threatened you sertously; he must either have given up his ambition or faced a war as dangerous as before (36). I have said enough to remind you of the real culprits. I pray heaven to avert the peril which would most clearly prove my charges; for I would rather have the guilty escape than involve all in their fall (37).

suni/statai, ‘is gathering’; the metaphor is from a storm, as may be safely inferred from the following words. The crash of the thunder is not yet so loud but that we can hear one another speak. In Dem. 18. 62 tou= sunistame/nou kai\ fuome/nou kakou=, the figure seems rather to be taken from the gathering of morbid humours to a head.
ti/s, direct for indirect. The reference is to Aeschines.
tw=n e)/cw pragma/twn, ‘your interests abroad’; u(pe\r, as often, is synonymous with peri/.
ge/gonen, ‘has come into existence,’ ‘really dates its birth from.’
e)kei/nh|, the day of the assembly (July 16, 346) at which the Athenians lost their last opportunity of saving Thermopylae and Phocis.
a)\n h)=n, ‘there would have been,’ either ‘ever since then’ or (better) ‘at the present time.’

sto/lw| repeats the idea already expressed in nau=si, but goes with h)=lqen as nau=si with krath/sas: both are contrasted with pezh=| badi/zwn, the latter word being regularly used of land-marching. The aorist indicative in the apodosis (with a)\n) here, as often, does not refer to a past event nor imply the truth of the contradictory statement. Such implication is only necessarily involved in the protasis.
u(pe/r, ‘making his way past,’ rarely used in a local sense.
di) o(/n, either supply e)kei/nw| (dative after o(moi/w|) as antecedent, or suppose that the relative is used after o(/moios on the analogy of toiou=tos, as in Plato, Rep. 590 o(/moios oi(=os.

w(s me\n u(pomnh=sai (with i(kanw=s), ‘for a reminder to you,’ lit. ‘regarded as (uttered) to remind you.’ The infinitive is used absolutely with w(s, as not uncommonly, though oftenest in stereo
typed phrases such as w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n: sometimes also without w(s, as in e)moi\ dokei=n.

w(s d' a)\n e)cetasqei/h, lit. ‘how my words might be tested,’ so ‘as to any way in which (or conditions under which) my words,’ etc. The construction is somewhat like that of w(s a)\n ei)/poite in § 3.
ou)de/na, with the principal verb, instead of mhde/na with the infinitive; cf. § 33.
di/kaio/s e)sti, personal construction preferred, as often, to the impersonal di/kaio/n e)stin au)to\n a)polwle/nai.

th=s (sc. pa/ntwn) zhmi/as, governed by meta/. For the order cf. Dem. 8. 3 toi=s peri\ tw=n a)/llwn qoru/bois kai\ tai=s (sc. peri\ tw=n a)/llwn) kathgori/ais. Both Philocrates and Aeschines were brought to trial in the following year.

§ 1-5 Introduction (prooi/mion). We are always discussing the wrongs we endure from Philip, but yet things are so bad that they could not be worse (1). Of many reasons for this the chief is the action of those who aim at popularity rather than patriotism. They occupy your attention so fully that Philip can do what he likes unmolested (2). I must ask you to listen calmly if I speak with freedom: freedom of speech is strangely excluded from our debates (3). The result is that while you listen with delight to complaisant rhetoric, you are involved in extreme perils. If you are now willing to listen without prejudice, I will speak: it is yet possible to retrieve our losses (4). The worst factor in past events affords most hope for the future—I mean the fact that it is by complete neglect of your duties that you have come into this plight. Otherwise there were no hope; but as things are it is only Athenian negligence, not Athens herself, that Philip has defeated (5).

o)li/gou dei=n, an absolute use of the infinitive, of uncertain origin. It may perhaps have been a dative (‘for lacking little’ and so ‘so as to lack little’): take it with e(ka/sthn, ‘almost every.’ Cf. Dem. 18. 269 mikrou= dei=n o(/moio/n e)sti tw=| o)neidi/zein.
w(=n, for e)kei/nwn a)\ (internal accusative with a)dikei=).
a)f' ou)=, i.e. 346 B.C. ‘The peace’ throughout this speech means the peace of Philocrates.
tou\s a)/llous, sc. *(/ellhnas, which is inserted in some MSS.
oi)=d' o(/ti, parenthetic, as in Phil. 2. 29.
a)\n with fhsa/ntwn representing a subordinate clause containing the optative with a)/n, as regularly. Supply a condition (e.g. ‘if called upon’).
tou=to, to be explained from the following words, le/gein kai\ pra/ttein k.t.e(.

pra/ttein, as a verb implying endeavour, is normally followed by an object-clause containing o(/pws with the future indicative. Logically, though not exactly in grammar, the object-clause belongs
also to le/gein, which acquires a suggestion of endeavour from its association with pra/ttein.
ei)s tou=to without a genitive (e.g. talaipwri/as), as in Phil. 2. 2.
u(phgme/na, ‘misguided,’ ‘brought by stealthy (u(po\) malpractices.’ Cf. Phil. 2. 31 u(ph/xqhte.

bla/sfhmon me/n. As frequently, the me\n-clause in thought is subordinate to the de\-clause. The orator fears that his words may prove true: he knows that they are ill-omened. It is often best to translate in such cases by a concessive clause: here render ‘I fear lest, though a sinister phrase, it may prove true to say that’ etc.
pario/ntes, cf. Phil. 2. 3.
h)/melle e(/cein, the equivalent in past time of the future indicative in present time, e(/cei, used after the relative with a final sense.
a)\n with du/nasqai, equivalent to o(/ti a)\n e)du/nato: ou) also belongs to the infinitive.
para/, causal as in Phil. 1. 11.
eu(rh/sete, sc. ta\ pra/gmat' ei)s tou=t) a)figme/na.
tine\s me/n, blind conservatives, perhaps hinting at Eubulus.
du/nantai, absolutely, ‘are powerful,’ as often.
tau=ta, antecedent to oi(=s.
ou)kou=n k.t.e(.; see Introd.

e)pi\ toi=s pra/gmasin, ‘in charge of affairs.’ It must always be remembered that the British ministry had no counterpart at Athens. All matters of general policy were determined as occasion arose by the e)kklhsi/a, and the phrase here used means no more than those politicians who were responsible for proposing the policy at present adopted.
o(/pws, with the future indicative, forms an object-clause after poiou=sin.
par' au(th=s, identifying the city with the citizens, i.e. with those anti-Macedonian politicians whose overthrow is sought.
peri\ tou=to, ‘engaged upon this.’ Cf. Thuc. VII.31 o)/nti d' au)tw=| peri\ tau=ta.
pra/ttein and poiei=n, cf. Phil. 1. 5.
politei=ai, ‘political courses,’ an unusual sense. Cf. Aeschin. 75. 3 h( *kleofw=ntos politei/a.
parrhsi/an. Athenian liberty of speech is a common topic in literature.
e)pi/, ‘in the case of.’ tw=n a)/llwn is neuter.
tou= sumbouleu/ein, ‘public debates.’
e)n me\n tai=s e)kklhsi/ais. The rest of the sentence is repeated from Dem. 8. 34.
pro\s h(donh/n, normally with verbs of speaking, here transferred to a verb of listening: ‘hearing nothing but flattering assurances.’
gignome/nois, practically synonymous with pra/gmasi. Both are contrasted with the mere words of the e)kklhsi/a.
ti/, direct for indirect. What is the mood of le/gw?
e(/toimos with ei)mi\ omitted, as in Phil. 1. 29.
to\ xei/riston t.k.e(., repeated from Phil. 1. 2. See notes on that passage. Here the orator prefixes an introduction to soften the effect.
th=s po/lews de/. The postponement of de\ adds emphasis to po/lews.
ou)de\ keki/nhsqe, ‘you have not so much as stirred’ or ‘been aroused.’ Other interpretations ignore the uses of kinei=n elsewhere.

§ 6-75 Discussion (a)po/deicis) including (1) a general sketch of the position of affairs (dih/ghsis) §§ 6—46, (2) proposals (pro/qesis) and arguments in support of them (pi/steis), which in this speech are blended, §§ 47—75.

§ 6-7 If it was admitted that Philip is making war on us, the orator's only duty would have been to propose measures of resistance. But since in spite of his aggressions some declare that the anti-Macedonians at Athens are responsible for his hostility, we must first settle whether the decision between peace and war rests with us (6), lest those who suggest plans for defence should be called the authors of war (7).
On this and the next section see Introd. § 23.
o(/pws ... a)munou/meqa , best taken as a dependent interrogative clause, rather than as an object-clause.
e)/nioi, i.e., that section of the public which listens favourably to the pro-Macedonian speakers.
a)ne/xesqai, used absolutely with a genitive absolute attached as not infrequently. It also takes an accusative.
h(mw=n tines, i.e. the anti-Macedonian politicians (sc. by driving Philip to retaliation).
diorqou=sqai peri\ tou/tou, ‘put things straight for ourselves in this matter,’ i.e. ‘make our position herein clear.’

w(s a)munou/meqa, a curious form after verbs of proposing and advising, which normally take an infinitive, but can also take a
dependent interrogative clause or an object-clause (o(/pws with fut. indic.): w(s is not used in such object-clauses in Attic prose; but the case here seems to be that of a relative used with the future in a final sense. ‘Proposing measures whereby we shall defend ourselves,’ almost equivalent to ‘proposing that we shall defend ourselves.’
prw=ton, predicative, ‘I lay down and define this as the first of all the points we have to discuss.’
ei), ‘namely, whether,’ explanatory of tou=to.

§ 8-9 If it rests with us to maintain peace, let us do so, and let those who think so shew us the way. But if an enemy in force, while talking of peace, acts as if at war, we must resist, though we may call it peace if you like (8). A peace which is to enable Philip to subdue the rest of Greece before attacking us is wholly one-sided, and it is to procure such a peace that Philip is spending his money (9).
gra/fein, ‘propose measures’ such as to secure that the peace will not injure our interests.
e(/teros, ‘another,’ meaning of course Philip.
proba/llei, ‘puts forward’ as a plea, ‘shelters himself behind.’
fa/skein, placed first for emphasis; best taken as dependent on bou/lesqe, though it may be absolute (‘as for professing’).
tau/thn is object of u(polamba/nei, assimilated in gender to its predicative supplement ei)rh/nhn.
e)kei/nw| par' u(mw=n, ‘from you towards him,’ ‘observed by you towards him.’ This and the following phrase serve as predicative supplements to th\n ei)rh/nhn, just as an adjective might.
tou=to, explained by the infinitive-clauses at the end of the sentence.
xrhma/twn, genitive of price.
polemei=sqai, passive (with personal subject) of a verb properly intransitive.

§ 10-14 It would be madness to wait until Philip declares war: we know from previous examples that he will never do so (10). He pretended amity till the last moment towards the Olynthians and the Phocians (11), as well as towards the Thessalians and Oreus (12). And if his policy is thus to beguile people who could in no case have opposed him, is he likely to treat you more openly (13)? No: he would be a fool thus to unite your quarrelling factions against himself and deprive his Athenian supporters of their great argument (14).
ei)...perimenou=men, with apodosis in present indicative, ‘if we are going to wait.’

badi/zh|, properly used of marching by land (Phil. 2. 36), is to be taken with to\n *peiraia= by a kind of zeugma, as the Piraeus must be singled out for mention as the possible object of an attack by sea.
oi(=s, i.e. e)kei/nois (the usual instrumental with tekmai/resqai) a(/.
tou=to me/n, ‘in the first place,’ answered by tou=to de/; the use is frequent in Herodotus and not rare in the orators.
a)pe/xwn. The present participle is used somewhat pregnantly: almost ‘it was only when he was within forty stades that he,’ etc.

duoi=n qa/teron, accusative with no expressed government, as commonly in the case of this expression. We might supply gene/sqai, to which d. q. would be subject; but the ellipse had probably ceased to be felt.
au)to/n, emphatic, ‘he himself’: supply mh\ oi)kei=n. It is not necessary that mh\ should be repeated, and it is far-fetched to supply oi)kei=n only and render ‘he must confine himself to Macedonia.’
a)/llon, i.e., ‘preceding.’
a)ganaktw=n, participle of the imperfect: so also pe/mpwn.
ei)s *fwke/as, ‘into Phocis.’ w(s pro\s summa/xous is an exaggeration.
h)/rizon, ‘maintained against all opposition.’
pa/rodon, substantive corresponding to parelqei=n, of passing Thermopylae.
prw/hn. The reference is to Philip's seizure of the city in 342 B.C.
ta\ teleutai=a, accusative used adverbially (originally of a cognate character).
*)wrei/tais. Cf. §§ 33 and 59 sqq. The allusion is to the events of 342 B.C. The dative depends most probably on pepomfe/nai.
e)piskeyome/nous, used especially of visiting the sick.
punqa/nesqai. Note the tense. The present of such verbs (esp. a)kou/w) is used (like ‘I hear,’ ‘I learn’ in English) rather loosely.
kai\ stasia/zousi gives a more explicit equivalent of nosou=si (kai\=‘that is,’ as frequently). Cobet would omit the words on the ground that they weaken the point.
ei)=ta, ‘after these instances.’
e)poi/hsan ... a)/n . The suppressed protasis is to this effect—‘if he had not sought to deceive them.’
mh\ paqei=n, because e)fula/canto implies the notion of hindering or preventing.
ai(rei=sqai, present of regular practice. So prole/gonta, ‘giving warning’ on each occasion.
prorrh/sews, substantive corresponding to prole/gw, as a)po/rrhsis to a)pagoreu/w. The aorist proeipei=n occurs in § 14.
mhde\n e)gkalou/ntwn, not ou)de/n, because, though the participle refers to actual fact, the negative is determined by the conditional character of the clause.

filoniki/an. It is doubtful, here and elsewhere, whether we should read filoneiki/an (given here by the MSS.). The question is whether the Attic writers really used two words, one derived from ni/kh, the other from nei=kos.
a)naba/llousin, ‘they put you off,’ ‘make you defer action.’

§ 15-17 No one is so stupid as to decide by words rather than by actions whether another is at war with him. Consider then Philip's acts. Immediately after peace was concluded, he took some of your possessions and expelled your garrisons (15). Was not this war? These were perhaps trifles, but moral principles know not of great and small. Again, take his present action in the Chersonese (16). He says that he is not at war; but I declare that by every act of interference in Megara and elsewhere he is breaking the peace. Preparations for attack are as truly war as the attack itself (17).
eu)= fronw=n, ‘in his right mind.’
*diopei/qous, despatched to the Chersonese in charge of Athenian colonists not very long after the peace had been concluded.
e)n *xerronh/sw| nu=n, with o)/ntwn, a somewhat unusual order being adopted, apparently, for reasons of euphony.

*se/rrion, a headland on the southern coast of Thrace, west of the Hebrus, near the mouth of which Doriscus lay. If we are to distinguish the ‘Serrhian fort’ from Serrhium itself, the implication is that Philip first occupied the ground which commanded the headland, and then drove out the garrison of the fort. The exact position of the *(iero\n o)/ros is uncertain, but it must have been in the same district.
The imperfects are ‘narrative imperfects,’ giving a more graphic effect than aorists.
tou\s e)k *s. tei/xous. The preposition, as commonly, is chosen (instead of e)n) to suit the verb.
strathgo/s, i.e. Chares (Aesch. 2. 90).

w)mwmo/kei, a very barefaced mis-statement. These operations took place after peace had been concluded at Athens and
sworn to by the Athenians, but before the Athenian envoys had administered the oaths to Philip. When he has another purpose in view Demosthenes gives the true version (18. 25, 26; 19. 155, 156). Some would read ei)rh/nh me\n ga\r w)mw/moto. The de\-clause suggested by the me\n here (‘but this was not peace’) is left to the imagination.
mhdei/s. Aeschines at a later date actually raised this objection (Aesch. 3. 82).
ei) is either (1) conditional—‘if they are trifling, or if Athens did not care about them, that is another (i.e. an irrelevant) argument’—or (2) interrogative—‘whether..., that is another question.’
e)pi\ mikrou=, ‘in the case of a trifling matter.’

th\n au)th\n e)/xei du/namin, ‘have the same force,’ i.e. a breach of their laws is equally wicked. eu)sebe\s refers to the religious obligation of the oath, di/kaion to human conceptions of what is fair.

*xerro/nhson. Philip had sent troops to the support of Cardia, which denied the claim of Athens to supremacy over her, and claimed independence. The orator is trying to put the worst face upon the matter. Nothing definite is known of this universal admission of the Athenians' right to the Chersonese, but the inhabitants themselves, except at Cardia, welcomed Diopithes cheerfully.
tau=ta, i.e. to\ o(mologei=n. Cf. Dem. 8. 16 and 8. 64.

a(pto/menon, ‘interfering with,’ referring to an attempt made by Megarian sympathisers to betray the city in 343 B.C., which seems to have been frustrated by Athenian troops under Phocion (Plutarch, Phocion 16, Dem. 9. 27).
turanni/das, in Eretria (inf. § 58) and Oreus (inf. § 62).

e)pi\ *qra/|khn. Christ is possibly right in wishing to read *qra/|khs, as the Athenians would be affected less by Philip's operations against Thrace than by those in the direction of Thrace, i.e. against their own possessions in that quarter.
skeuwrou/menon, ‘using intrigues upon.’
meta\ would naturally imply personal accompaniment, so that some editors are perhaps justified in preferring an old variant dia/.
ei) mh\ kai/, used like nisi forte, to introduce an alternative possibility which is so improbable that it serves merely to confirm what has preceded.
e)fista/ntas. Note the tense; ‘men who are erecting batteries for an assault.’

oi(=s a)\n e)gw\ lhfqei/hn, an instance of the quasi-final use of a relative with a)\n and the optative, almost equivalent to oi(=s e)gw\ lhfqh/somai. The selection of the first person as a mere equivalent for an indefinite pronoun is rare in Greek; but cf. Dem. 23. 55.

p.hi: In case of a breach your interests would be endangered in the Hellespont, in Megara, in Euboea, in the Peloponnese. In all these quarters his preparations are proceeding; and are we to say that he is keeping the peace?

div2.p: ti/sin, either (1) causal, ‘owing to what,’ or (2) instrumental of the thing risked, as in th=| yuxh=| kinduneu/ein. The latter gives a more natural turn to the expression, but if we take it so we must assume a slight change of ground in the reply, as the datives expected would then be tw=| *(ellhspo/ntw|, etc.
ti, euphemistically, ‘anything untoward.’
fronh=sai, ‘come to feel,’ an ingressive aorist like basileu=sai, ‘to become king.’
tou=to, used pregnantly, ‘such as is indicated in the foregoing.’

§ 19-20 I say that he has been at war with us ever since he destroyed the Phocians, and you must resist at once, if at all. Indeed I venture to think that you ought not now to discuss the case of the Chersonese and Byzantium (19), but to act at once for their defence and make the general peril of Greece the subject of your discussions. I will give reasons for my fears (20).
a)f' h(=s h(me/ras, for a)p' e)kei/nhs th=s h(me/ras e)n h(=|. The attraction seems to us curiously needless where a)po\ tau/ths follows, but cf. Phil. 2. 17.
dunh/sesqe. The influence of fhmi\ is no longer operative: some however prefer to read dunh/sesqai, suggested by Reiske.
ou)de\ dokei=. The force of the ou)de\ is to this effect—‘I disapprove this suggestion as well (as their other views).’ Emphasis falls on skopei=n.

mh/ ti pa/qwsi. This construction, which strictly belongs to verbs of fearing, is frequently used after other verbs when fear or danger is implied. In Dem. 18. 161 parathrei=n is followed by o(/pws and a future indicative.
e)c w(=n, with antecedent understood, ‘the grounds on which.’
i(/na k.t.e(. Compare Phil. 2. 6.

The opinion of the listeners is not to be formed until they have heard all. The
latter clause would become an iambic trimeter by the substitution of e)a\n for a)/n.
tetufw=sqai, probably ‘to be conceited and silly’ from tu=fos: but Harpocration derived it from tufw\s and took it rather to mean ‘to be mad’ (e)mbebronth=sqai).
u(giai/nonti, of mental soundness.

§ 21-22 I need not point out that Philip's power has risen from small beginnings, that Greece is disunited, and that he is now far more formidable than he was (21). Yet Greece has made to him a concession which all our previous wars were fought to avoid; I mean that he is allowed to do as he pleases, wronging and enslaving city after city (22).

to\ kat' a)rxa/s, accusative of time, like to\ prw=ton, also in Dem. 1. 12 and 2. 6. An old variant is tou= kat' a)rxa/s, which also seems to be possible Greek (e)k tou= kat' a)rxa\s mikrou= kai\ tapeinou=).
au(tou/s, for a)llh/lous, as in Phil. 1. 10.

h)=n is bracketed by Blass on rhythmical grounds and because e)sti\ would suit the sense better. The latter is no sound reason, as the tense is chosen to suit the nearer clause and e)sti\ can easily be supplied with nu=n.
gene/sqai and poih/sasqai both refer to time relatively future, but, as frequently, the aorist infinitive being by nature ‘timeless’ is employed.
a)f' u(mw=n a)rcame/nous, ‘beginning with you,’ ‘and you first of all.’

kaq' e(/na, like kaq' e(/kaston, is not infrequently used, as here, instead of a case of e(/kastos, and may have a genitive (here tw=n *(ellh/nwn) depending on it. The use seems to be due to a confusion of tou\s *(/ellhnas kaq' e(/na and e(/kaston tw=n *(ellh/nwn. Cf. Dem. 2. 24, tou\s a)/llous sesw/kate polla/kis pa/ntas kai\ kaq' e(/n) au)tw=n e)n me/rei. Phil. 1. 20.

periko/ptein, properly ‘to chip off pieces,’ used of the mutilation of the Hermae: the word seems to be here used figuratively of successive acts of spoliation (some however assume a second significance).
e)pio/nta. The tense implies a repeated action.

§ 23-24 No, when Athens or Sparta went too far, all Greece combined in resistance (24). Indeed Athens and Sparta quarrelled over wrongs done not to themselves but to others. Now Philip has done more wrongs in less time than Athens and Sparta combined (25). Not to speak of his destruction of the Chalcidian cities and the Phocians, there is his enslavement of Thessaly (26) and of Euboea, his insolent language and his general aggressiveness (27). Yet Greece does not combine to oppose him, but is so weak and disunited that she can take no concerted action (28). Each seems determined to put off the evil day for himself, instead of working for the common good, while the peril which threatens every one sooner or later is unquestionable (29).
The Athenian h(gemoni/a is reckoned from 476 to 404, inclusive, the Spartan from 404 to 376 (the battle of Naxos).

i)/sxusan (ingressive aorist) is somewhat depreciatory (especially with ti attached) as compared with prosta/tai which implies a recognised headship. Theban influence, which reached its fullest extent after Leuctra (371), did not survive the death of Epaminondas in 362.
o(/ ti bou/loisqe, a general relative clause in past time (optative of indefinite frequency), poiei=n being the present of repeated action, ‘to make a practice of doing.’

ou)de\ pollou= dei=, exactly equivalent in meaning to pollou= ge kai\ dei=. The ou)de\ in this phrase, which is used by Demosthenes alone of the Attic prose writers, seems to be simply an emphatic repetition of the preceding negative in an illogical position; it seems wrong to put a stop after ou)de/, as was formerly done by some editors.
tou=to me/n, adverbial as in § 11; here answered by kai\ pa/lin.

ma=llon de/. The correction is suggested by the thought that it seems unwise to associate the present audience with the discredit of their predecessors: elsewhere, in speaking of the past glories of Athens, Demosthenes makes his contemporaries partakers in the actions of their ancestors.
tisin, with prosfe/resqai, alluding especially to Megara and Potidaea, as the Athenian treatment of those cities contributed to the outbreak of the Peloponnesian War.
a)/rcasi, ingressive aorist.
dunastei/an, a word of somewhat less favourable significance than h(gemoni/a, properly applied to the government of an individual or an oligarchy.
ta\ kaqesthko/ta, ‘established institutions,’ in allusion to the Spartan practice of setting up oligarchical governments.
tou\s a)/llous. Demosthenes refrains from mentioning Theban aggression, because he was now endeavouring to secure cooperation between Thebes and Athens.
a)/n, with e)/xontes, equivalent to o(/te ou)k a)\n ei)/xomen (sc. ei) e)de/hse).
u(pe\r w(=n, for u(pe\r e)kei/nwn a(/, the relative being a cognate accusative with a)dikou/menoi.

oi(=s. Either supply e)n from the preceding, or (better) take as attracted from accusative of time. e)pipola/zei, ‘has been prominent.’ The initial date must be 353, in which year Philip took Methone from Athens, defeated the Phocians in Thessaly, and threatened Thermopylae.

ou)de\ me/ros, ‘not so much as a fraction.’ Elsewhere the phrase does not seem to occur, whereas there are parallels for ou)de\n me/ros, suggested here by E. Müller. The MSS. give ou)de\ pe/mpton me/ros (first hand in S and L) or ou)de\ pollosto\n me/ros.
Olynthus, with the 32 towns of the Olynthian league, was destroyed in 348 B.C.; Methone was captured in 353. Of the fate of Apollonia, an Ionian colony in Mygdonia, we have no definite knowledge.
mhd' ei), ‘not (with r(a/|dion)...so much as whether’: with proselqo/nta supply tina/.
ta\s politei/as, ‘their constitutions,’ by establishing new governments composed of his own partisans: ta\s po/leis, ‘their cities,’ by depriving them of their independence.
tetrarxi/as, of the four districts into which he divided Thessaly. See on Phil. 2. 22, dekadarxi/an.
e)n *eu)boi/a|, Eretria (inf. 57, 58) and Oreus (inf. 59—62).
ou) gra/fei. The negative covers both clauses, denying the negative in the second, as in inf. 57 and Dem. 18. 179 ou)k ei)=pon me\n tau=ta, ou)k e)/graya de/.
*)ambraki/an, early in 342, but unsuccessfully. The place was important as commanding an easy passage by sea into the Peloponnese.
*)=hlin, where his oligarchical friends had massacred the democrats in 343.
*mega/rois. Cf. sup. 17.
a)ganaktou=men, of the outward expression of resentment, ‘protest.’

diorwru/gmeqa. The preposition, as is proved by the addition of kata\ po/leis, must here imply division. It is doubted whether the ‘digging’ meant is of trenches or of underground mines: the former seems preferable, ‘we are so completely cut off from one another as it were by trenches (or canals).’
ou)de/, ‘no, nor,’ not to be confused with the preceding ou)/te.
kerdh=nai (or kerda=nai: the spelling is uncertain) ‘to profit by.’
e(/kastos, singular in apposition to h(mei=s, here determines the number throughout the rest of the sentence.
e)pei/. The connexion of the thought is ‘I say this, because it is clear that he will sooner or later threaten the existence of every state in Greece.’
peri/odos and katabolh\ seem to have been used technically of the recurring attacks of intermittent diseases.
a)festa/nai, ‘to be far removed’ from the danger.

§ 30-31 If Spartans or Athenians did wrong to other Greeks, they were Greeks themselves, and might be compared to a true-born heir who wastes his patrimony (30): if the same waste were committed by a pretender, far greater indignation would be aroused. Yet there is no such indignation against Philip though he is a contemptible Macedonian (31).
a)ll' ou)=n...ge, ‘at any rate,’ ‘at the worst’: in this connexion a)lla\ (apparently owing to a brachylogical or elliptical use) has lost its coordinating force.
gnhsi/wn, sc. paidw=n.
w(/sper a)/n, sc. u(pe/labe, on which depend ei)=nai and e)nei=nai below. The subject of ei)=nai is au)to\n (the heir): the w(s-clause depends on le/gein.
kat' au)to\ me\n tou=to, ‘so far as that goes.’
kathgori/as, probably not used in the technical sense, though at Athens one who squandered his inheritance was liable to be deprived of the right to speak in the Assembly.
e)lumai/neto is not a mere synonym of a)pw/llue: the latter alludes chiefly to throwing away money, the former to injuring (e.g. by neglect of repairs) the estate.
ou(/tws e)/xousin, ‘they take this attitude,’ the same attitude of strong disapproval. ou)x is repeated for emphasis.
o(/qen, sc. ei)=nai/ tina, ‘of which one can decently call a man a native.’
o)le/qrou, ‘pestilent,’ used almost as an adjective. Cf. Dem. 18. 127, o)/leqros grammateu/s.

a)ndra/podon. The orator is assigning an invidious reason for the absence of a slave-trade in Macedonia; the real reason was doubtless the superior civilisation of that country, as compared with Thrace and the Asiatic countries from which slaves were usually imported, and its connexion with Greece.

§ 32-35 Yet his outrages go far enough. He destroys Greek cities, presides over the Pythia, holds Thermopylae, takes precedence at the oracle (32), acts as dictator of Thessaly, and interferes in Euboea. But Greece endures him, as if he were a divine visitation, without attempting resistance (33). Not only are common insults to all Greece unavenged, but no state attempts retaliation for its own wrongs. He has injured Corinth, Achaia, Thebes (34), and Athens; but yet we sit idly watching one another. Is not the eventual doom of each clear enough (35)?
ti/qhsi, ‘holds,’ i.e. ‘presides at,’ in pursuance of an Amphictyonic decree. Philip presided in person in 346 and by a deputy (any subject of a monarch might be invidiously termed dou=los) in 342.
kai\ tw=n ... paro/dwn , ‘that is, of the pass,’ emphasising its importance.
tou/tous, i.e. in the neighbourhood of Thermopylae.

promantei/an, the right of precedence in consulting the Delphic oracle. Precedence over others was enjoyed by those states which belonged to the Amphictyonic League, and was occasionally conferred upon others, e.g. on Croesus. How the order among those who possessed this right was determined, we do not know; the following words may suggest that it was fixed by the Amphictyons. Among other applicants precedence was assigned by lot.
*porqmo/n, the port in the territory of Euboea. See the fuller narrative in 57, 58, and, for Oreus, 59—62.
xa/lazan. Hailstorms often did serious damage in Greece. Men regard Philip as no less completely beyond their own control than the weather.
kaq' e(autou/s, ‘where they are.’
ou) mo/non. The negative is not repeated in ou)dei/s, but the first belongs to mo/non only.
e)f' oi(=s, ‘on the ground of the wrongs which’; u(pe\r w(=n is substituted in the following clause merely for the sake of variety.
h)/dh, ‘by this time,’ with tou=to, ‘this, when we come to it,’ so ‘this, if anything.’ The use is idiomatic and fairly common.
*)ambraki/an. Cf. § 27. With the genitives, which are possessive, a participle of ei)=nai may be supplied.

*nau/pakton. It belonged originally to the Locrians who were ousted by Messenians: the tenure of the latter was of advantage to Athens during the Peloponnesian War. The Spartans restored it to the Locrians after the war, but they were again driven out by the Achaeans in 367.
*)exi=non, founded by Thebes on the northern shore of the Maliac gulf, in Thessalian territory.

summa/xous, sc. au(tw=|, according to most editors, who compare a parallel passage in Dem. 18. 87 where au(tw=| is added. The effect, however, is very awkward, as we should expect some reason to be given why an attack upon Byzantium should injure Thebes (it will hardly be maintained that the party injured is Byzantium herself), nor could Byzantium be described as *qhbai/wn. It seems better therefore to understand *qhbai/ois and suppose that there was an alliance between Thebes and Byzantium, not recorded elsewhere (though an inscription records pecuniary assistance given by Byzantium to Thebes during the Sacred War).
e)w= ta)/lla, a)lla\ is parenthetic.
*kardi/an. Cf. § 16. The claim of Athens to Cardia was never admitted either by the inhabitants or by Philip.
malakizo/meqa. A variant recorded by ancient writers is malki/omen (‘we are torpid’) which seems to give rather better sense and is supported by several modern editors.
ble/pomen, in the hope that some one else may take the initiative. A fuller expression of the same idea occurs in Dem. 14. 15: cf. Sallust, Cat. 52, alius alium expectantes cunctamini.
kaq' e(/na. Cf. § 22.
ti/, repeated for rhetorical effect.

§ 36-40 There is a reason for this deterioration in Greece. Formerly there was an element in public feeling which preserved Greek freedom against all assaults, but now its loss has ruined us (36). In those days men who took pay from an enemy were detested and heavily punished (37), so that none was found to sell our opportunities, our concord, or our distrust of despots and foreigners (38). But now there is a regular traffic in these things: the traitor is envied or laughed at, and his accuser is disliked (39). Our material
resources have greatly increased, but treachery robs them of all value (40).
a)/neu lo/gou, ‘irrationally,’ not quite synonymous with a)/neu ai)ti/as.
nu=n, sc. e)/xousin.

h)=ge, more usually dih=ge. The use of the uncompounded verb is a touch of poetical colouring, helping to give elevation to the passage, as does the personification of the ti, and the turn of the phrases e)kra/thse plou/tou and ma/xhs h(tta=to.
a)/nw kai\ ka/tw. Cf. Phil. 1. 41, where kai\ is omitted. The idea is that of confused and random movement, not exactly ‘upside down.’
poiki/lon, ‘intricate.’
xalepw/taton, ‘very serious.’
parai/thsis, ‘possibility of begging off,’ deprecatio.
e(ka/stou tw=n pragma/twn, ‘for each action,’ or possibly ‘in each affair.’
prosexo/ntwn, sc. to\n nou=n, a common ellipse. For all Philip's devotion to business and the slackness of Athens, chance is sure to give her some opportunities to score successes against him.
a)pisti/an. Cf. Phil. 2. 24.
w(/sper e)c a)gora=s, ‘as if from open market,’ emphasises the freedom and regularity of the traffic.
e)kpe/pratai, ‘have been sold away’ (from the country), ‘exported,’ answering to a)nteish=ktai, ‘have been imported in exchange.’
u(f' w(=n. The antecedent supplied is subject to a)nteish=ktai. In the following passage the ‘particular’ condition (ei) ei)/lhfen) is almost indistinguishable from the ‘general’ (a)\n o(mologh=|).
e)legxome/nois, present participle of repeated occurrence.
tou/tois, almost certainly neuter, ‘this behaviour.’
e)pei\...ge introduces a confirmation of the explanation just given of the present weakness of Greece in the denial of an alternative explanation.

xrhma/twn may be taken with plh=qos or with a)fqoni/a. The former seems better, as ‘men’ and ‘money’ are frequently coupled in such a connexion, and sw/mata and xrh/mata are words of the same formation.
oi(=s, with kri/noi rather than with i)sxu/ein.
tw=n to/te, for h)\ toi=s to/te.
a)/xrhsta k.t.e(. For the asyndeton cf. Phil. 1. 36.
u(po\ because gi/gnetai (as commonly) is practically the passive of poiei=n.

§ 41-46 Of the present state of affairs you need no proof: to shew how different things were in the past I will cite an inscription deposited in the Acropolis (41), which declares Arthmius of Zelea an outlaw because he brought Persian gold into the Peloponnese (42). Why did Athens take so strong a step in a case so little connected with her (43)? Common outlawry would have been no great hardship. But the special nature of this outlawry appears from the homicide laws; it meant that he might be put to death with impunity (44). This severe measure is proof of our ancestors' determination to uphold the common prosperity of Greece. And so Greece was then formidable to her foes (45). But what is the case now (46)?

tau=ta, ‘what I have described,’ to which ta\ me\n nu=n and ta\ d' e)n toi=s a)/. x. stand in apposition. Blass is perhaps right in wishing to omit e)mou=, on the ground that an orator produces witnesses but would not act as one.
a)/nwqen, ‘in earlier times’; the idiomatic use of the form in -qen arose from the same idea as the use of e)k noted in Phil. 1. 1.
ta)nanti/a, accusative used in place of the customary adverb with ei)=xen (a very uncommon form).
le/gwn governs gra/mmata by a slight zeugma.

ei)s a)kro/polin, without th\n, the word being almost a proper noun. Similarly po/lis, a)/stu, a)gora/. For the whole passage compare Dem. 19. 271 sq., Aeschin. 3. 258, Dinarchus 2. 24. Names of public benefactors and sometimes of public enemies were often recorded in this way.
au)toi=s, emphatic, ‘themselves.’

*puqw/naktos. In formal inscriptions of Attica no article is inserted where a man is described as ‘A the son of B.’ The MSS. are therefore almost certainly wrong in giving o( *puqw/naktos. Zelea was situated in the Troad, and was a member of the Delian confederacy. As Busolt suggests, it is probable that a decree of this kind would not be passed by the Athenian assembly before the League had practically become the empire of Athens. It is probable therefore that Plutarch is wrong in making Themistocles the proposer of this decree (a scholiast on Aristides gives the proposer as Cimon), and it has been plausibly suggested that Arthmius may have been connected with the despatch of Megabazus to Sparta in 455 (Thuc. I.109).
h( ai)ti/a. According to Deinarchus, this was the only instance in which a reason was given.

to\ a)ci/wma, i.e. o\ h)ci/oun, ‘that which they thought worthy’ of themselves, so their ‘conception of their duty,’ a use entirely distinct from the commoner use with a personal genitive (ou(= a)/n tis a)ciw/qh|).

dou=lon, subject of a monarch. Cf. Dem. 19. 69, despo/th| (Philip) diakonou=ntes, of Antipater and Parmenio. Correspondingly tw=| despo/th| below. Demosthenes would not recognise any obligation towards Persia as binding on a member of the Athenian confederacy, except to serve the immediate purpose of his argument.
xrusi/on, gold in its coined form; distinguished from xruso\s as a)rgu/rion from a)/rguros and bibli/on (book) from bi/blos (papyrus).
e)xqro\n substituted for the pole/mion of the inscription, as carrying a more invidious suggestion.
tou=to, neuter, less common than attraction to the gender of the predicate.
ou(twsi/, ‘simply,’ ‘in the ordinary way.’ ‘This is not the outlawry meant by the common use of the term.’
ti/ ga/r, sc. die/feren or e)/melen. tw=n is neuter, agreeing with koinw=n. If, as Aeschines says, Arthmius was pro/cenos of Athens, he would presumably lose some privileges.

u(pe\r w(=n, for u(pe\r e)kei/nwn w(=n, the latter genitive depending on fo/nou and being masculine; ‘with reference to those for killing whom he (the law-giver—a fairly common ellipse in speaking of laws) allows no prosecution.’
eu)age/s, an archaic word probably taken from one of the old laws of homicide. Cf. Andoc. 1. 96.
a)/timos probably in this connexion meant originally ‘without price,’ referring to pecuniary compensation to the relatives of the slain.

tou/twn, probably the persons specified in the law (the subject of le/gei being the law-giver), but it might mean Arthmius and his family, le/gei being used of the inscription. It seems to be clear enough that a)timi/a might include the loss of all claim to protection of life: cf. Plato Gorgias 508 D.
kai\ diafqei/rei, explanatory of w)nei=tai.
mh\ ... u(polamba/nousin , for ei) mh\ u(pela/mbanon.
e)ko/lazon regards punishment as corrective, e)timwrou=nto as retaliatory.
ta\ toiau=ta, probably corrupt practices, ta)/lla referring to other conduct calculated to injure the general interests of Greece.
paraplhsi/ws, sc. e)/xousi.
ei)/pw, deliberative, keleu/ete being parenthetic, like the common bou/lei or bou/lesqe in similar cases.

e)k tou= grammatei/ou a)nagignw/skei. It is difficult to conceive what sort of document would satisfy the requirements of the passage, giving either, to suit the shorter version of this section, proofs of the present slackness of the Athenians and its evil results, or, as the longer version demands, good counsel. On the other hand the question raised is not satisfactorily answered in the following context of the speech itself. It seems most reasonable to suppose that part of the original speech has been lost at this point.

§ 47-52 Our would-be comforters tell us that Philip is not so powerful as Sparta was once, when Athens nevertheless maintained her independence. But look at recent improvements in the art of war (47). Formerly there were merely summer campaigns, heavyarmed citizen troops, and no bribery (48). Now treachery is prevalent, pitched battles are rare and Philip's successes are largely due to his cavalry and light troops (49), and to his siege-engines: he fights, too, all the year round (50). We must then neglect antiquated precedents, seek to nip his projects in the bud and avoid a decisive struggle (51). Advantage lies with us for continuous warfare, but with him for a combat à outrance (52).
para/, ‘coming from,’ so ‘propounded by.’
u(fi/stato, ‘could withstand,’ most commonly with the accusative in this sense, though the dative is also used.
au)tou/s, in preference, as usual, to a repetition of the relative. Cf. Phil. 1. 35.
w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n. Cf. Phil. 2. 1.
kekinh=sqai, ‘have been disturbed,’ so ‘changed,’ explained by ka)pidedwke/nai.
th\n w(rai/an au)th/n, ‘just the season’; it is not clear what feminine substantive was originally omitted in this ellipse.
a)\n (after e)mbalo/ntas) belongs to a)nexw/roun; an example of the ‘iterative’ use of a)\n with imperfects.
politikoi=s, ‘consisting of citizens.’ The instrumental of persons is not uncommon in the case of military operations: similarly in Latin.
a)rxai/ws, ‘old-fashioned’: politikw=s, ‘true to their citizenship,’ i.e. to the ideals of a free Greek state.

ou)de\ ... par) ou)deno\s ou)de/n . The normal negative with an infinitive after w(/ste is of course mh/, and nearly all apparent exceptions are explained away by the consideration that, where they occur, the infinitive is simply an oblique infinitive representing a direct indicative (or optative with a)/n), which would require ou). In the present passage, it is possible, but unlikely, that the force of a)kou/w is still felt in spite of the return to the direct form at ei)=xon: or ei)=xon may be a corruption of e)/xein. There are parallel passages in which the same difficulty occurs: in Dem. 53. 1 it is an easy remedy to substitute e)chu=ron for e)ceurei=n, but the case in Lycurgus 3 is more stubborn. If the text of these passages is sound, it seems better to refer the exceptional use to a laxity of idiom than to seek for an intentional difference of significance.
e)k parata/cews, ‘by regular fighting’; cf. Phil. 1. 23 paratacome/nhn.
e)chrth=sqai, ‘keeping in attachment to himself,’ passive with ‘retained’ accusative, or possibly middle. The variant e)chrtu=sqai, ‘keeping himself equipped with,’ gives equally good sense.
As a matter of fact the Macedonian phalanx as improved by Philip was a factor of considerable importance in his military power.
nosou=ntas, used figuratively, as often, of disunion.
a)pisti/an, ‘mutual distrust.’
qe/ros kai\ xeimw=na, anticipatory accusatives, which we should express as subjects of the subordinate clause. The following clause is still under the government of siwpw= w(s.
e)cai/retos, ‘excepted’; its exact bearing is explained by h(\n dialei/pei.
ble/pontas, ‘keeping our eyes upon’ with the suggestion of using as a model.

e)ktraxhlisqh=nai, probably an equestrian metaphor, ‘to be thrown over one's horse's head,’ like a)naxaiti/zein. Xenophon uses the word in this sense. Some take the neck here to be that of the sufferer, either giving the word an original sense ‘have our necks wrenched,’ or taking it as a figure from wrestling (an intensified form of traxhli/zein, ‘to grip by the neck’).
w(s e)k plei/stou, either of place, ‘at as great a distance as possible,’ or of time, ‘as long beforehand as possible.’ The following final clause seems rather to favour the former interpretation.
sumplake/ntas, ‘coming to close grips,’ a figure taken from wrestling. Compare the advice of Pericles in the Peloponnesian War (Thuc. I.143).
pollh/n, assimilated in gender to h(=s. Cf. Phil. 1. 16 toi=s h(mi/sesin.

§ 53-55 Recognise this fact, take action, and above all set your faces against Philip's Athenian supporters (53). But you cannot do so: you are so mad (can it be a frenzy sent from heaven?) that you listen with amusement to the calumnies of these confessed hirelings (54). Worse still, you allow them more licence than true patriots. I will give you examples of the results which such folly brings (55).
logismw=|, causal dative, ‘from calculation,’ i.e. ‘from reasoned conviction’; dianoi/a|, ‘from deliberate resolve.’
mish=sai, ingressive aorist.

u(phretou=ntas, best taken with the article, in spite of the intrusion of kola/shte, though it is possible to take tou\s e)n th=| po/lei as object and u(phretou=ntas as a causal participle, ‘for serving.’

mwri/as has a moral significance, of not caring to do what should be done, which distinguishes it from paranoi/as, ‘perverted judgment.’ ou)k e)/xw ti/ le/gw (subjunctive) is substituted for a third genitive, for rhetorical effect.
daimo/nion, ‘supernatural.’

fqo/nou is best taken as referring to the malice of disputing speakers, since the words on either side of it clearly have that bearing: the sense is ‘in order to enjoy the spectacle of their reviling, their malice and their ribaldry.’

h(=stinos a)
 tu/xhte. Cf. Phil. 1. 46 o(/ti a)
 tu/xhte. Here the full form would be ai)ti/as e(/neka h(=stinos a)
 e(/neka tu/xhte tou=to poiou=ntes.

w(s ou)k ei)si/n. The negative is pleonastic, like the mh\ which regularly accompanies the infinitive after verbs of denial. The idiom is not uncommon: it appears after a)ntile/gein in Dem. 8. 31. Demosthenes is thinking of the shameless avowals of Philocrates; cf. Dem. 19. 114.

pw, ‘yet,’ as regards the course of the narrative—we have not yet come to the real deino/n. The corresponding adverb in a positive clause is h)/dh. In English we could not thus repeat the adjective without addition, but should say ‘this, bad as it is, is not the worst.’ Cf. Dem. 19. 113, kai\ ou)xi\ tou=to/ pw deino/n, thlikou=ton o)/n.
a)sfalei/as, perhaps in allusion to the speaker's unsuccessful prosecution of Aeschines peri\ parapresbei/as. e)/rga , ‘actual facts.’

§ 56-62 In Olynthus there was a Macedonian party and an anti-Macedonian. It was the former who betrayed the cavalry and lost the city (56). In Eretria the Macedonian party won favour, the people expelled their friends (57), and Philip first set despots over them and then drove them out altogether (58). In Oreus there was a Macedonian party, opposed by Euphraeus (59): he became unpopular, and when he attempted to overthrow his opponents he was arrested as a disturber (60). The people rejoiced, the Macedonian party pursued its way unchecked, and no resistance was made till the enemy was at the gates (61). Thus the city was captured, and the traitors now enjoy supreme power, while those who supported them have been exiled or put to death (62).

*fili/ppou, possessive, ‘belonging to Philip,’ so ‘on Philip's side’: the boldness of the impersonal possessive, tou= belti/stou, is softened by the fact that it follows and is parallel to the personal, *fili/ppou.
tou\s i(ppe/as, a body of 500, betrayed into Philip's hands by their own officers: cf. Dem. 19. 267.
sukofantou=ntes kai\ diaba/llontes, imperfect participles, parallel to fronou=ntes; the article belongs to all three.
*)apollwni/dhn, one of the leading democrats. It appears from a speech falsely attributed to Demosthenes that he received Athenian citizenship but was afterwards deprived of it.
pa/nta kaka/, ‘nothing but mischief,’ ‘mere havoc.’ The first negative in this sentence covers both clauses, and is not merely repeated in ou)damou=; cf. sup. § 27.

*plouta/rxou. He had been a nominal friend to Athens and it was on his application that the expedition of Phocion was sent to Euboea (350 or 348). He proved treacherous, but failed to prevent Phocion's victory at Tamynae. According to a scholiast, he afterwards told his mercenaries to get their pay from Athens, whereupon they seized and held to ransom a small Athenian force which had been left in Euboea.
ma=llon, sc. h)\ tw=n e)f' u(ma=s a)go/ntwn.
u(pe\r au(tw=n, ‘in their own real interests,’ direct reflexive referring to the subject of the more remote verb.
kai\ ga/r toi introduces an explanation of the participial clause in the preceding sentence.
*klei/tarxon, an Eretrian, the most important of Philip's supporters in Euboea. Cf. Dem. 18. 81, 82 and 18. 295. In the latter passage Hipparchus is also mentioned as one who betrayed Euboea.
di\s must be taken with boulome/nous, di\s h)/dh being equivalent to the more usual deu/teron h)/dh. The order of the words is strongly against taking di\s with e)celh/laken.
The dates of these occurrences are uncertain.
sw/|zesqai, i.e. to recover their independence.
*filisti/dhs, the chief pro-Macedonian in Oreus. Cf. Dem. 18. 81. His associates here mentioned are otherwise unknown.
*eu)frai=os, a pupil of Plato, who had been in considerable honour at the Macedonian court under Perdiccas.
u(po\ tou= dh/mou is regarded by Blass as an interpolation on the ground that the maltreatment would come, not from the people in general, but from the Macedonian party.
th=s a(lw/sews, the capture of Oreus by Philip's troops. Note the use of pro/teron as a preposition.
e)ne/deicen at Athens would refer to a special form of procedure— ‘laid an information against.’ Whether it would have the same technical use in reference to Euboea we cannot tell.
xorhgo/n, both as directing the affair and as providing the funds. The latter sense is uppermost, the former being given in prutaneuo/menoi.
a)pa/gousi, used at Athens of process by summary arrest: the following words seem to indicate that there was some colour of legality given to the proceeding.
a)potumpani/sai, ‘to cudgel away,’ so ‘to cudgel to death,’ as in Dem. 19. 137.
e)pith/deion, a somewhat vaguer synonym for a)/cion.
o(po/shs, for e)f' o(po/shs: e)pi\ almost of attendant circumstances, or perhaps rather ‘in possession of.’ Compare the uses in Phil. 1. 7 and 9.
kateskeua/zonto th\n pra=cin, ‘were making all arrangements for the execution of their plans.’
e)si/ga kai\ katepe/plhkto, ‘he held his tongue in consternation,’ almost a case of u(/steron pro/teron.
memnhme/noi agrees with the plural implied in ei)/ tis.
r(h=cai fwnh/n, a phrase of somewhat poetical colour in Attic, though Herodotus uses it freely. It suggests the idea of breaking through some constraint.
diaskeuasa/menoi, ‘with all preparations fully ordered,’ or, more particularly, ‘in battle array.’
h)mu/nonto and prou)di/dosan are either narrative imperfects or conative.
kai\ turannou=si, closer definition of a)/rxousi.
tou\s ... sw/|zontas ... kai\ ... o)/ntas , accusative of the combined object, with tou\s me\n and tou\s de\ in distributive apposition. The words refer to the people of Oreus in general.
e(autou/s, the Macedonian party, direct reflexive for indirect, as in sup. § 57, inf. § 63.
kaqarw=s, ‘purely,’ i.e. without taint of corruption.

§ 63-67 In these cases, as at Athens, the Macedonian party's popularity is due to the fact that a patriot is bound to propose salutary measures, while Philip's supporters can gain their ends by urging comfortable counsels (63). The patriots advised self-sacrifice, energy, caution; “no need,” said the others: and so throughout. Finally the commons, from sheer despair, allowed the traitors their way (64). This, I fear, may happen at Athens. I hope the choice may not be forced upon us; but if it is, death is better than truckling to Philip. Remember the recompense for their complaisance which has fallen to Oreus (65) and Eretria and Olynthus (66). It is folly to hope for a better fate than theirs and to imagine that the greatness of Athens will save you in spite of any negligence (67).

ti/, direct question, qauma/zete being parenthetic. We might have expected tou= with the infinitive in dependence on ai)/tion, but the accusative is well supported in a parallel passage (Dem. 8. 56) and it is not easy to set limits to the use of the articular infinitive in the accusative, nor to explain its origin.
h(/dion ... e)/xein , imperfect infinitive; for the phrase cf. Phil. 1. 53.
o(/per, sc. ai)/tio/n e)sti.
boulome/nois, concessive participle.
oi(=s, not instrumental, but by attraction for a(\, internal accusative with xari/zontai—‘in the very act of gratifying their audience.’
e)ke/leuon, sc. oi( me\n u(pe\r tou= belti/stou le/gontes: for the omission of oi( me\n cf. Hom. Il. 22. 157 th=| r(a paradrame/thn, feu/gwn, o( d' o)/pisqe diw/kwn.
e(/ws, ‘until at length.’ The sense of e)gkatelei/fqhsan, the reading of S, does not suit the circumstances.

ta)/lla, accusative not afterwards provided with anything to
govern it: the governing expression (e.g. e)poi/oun e(ka/teroi) being superseded by a more particular form, which involves other objects for its verbs.
e)f' oi(=s, ‘on the strength of which.’

e)/mellon. The subject is properly the patriotic speakers, but in thought includes their compatriots in general. The future infinitive with e)/mellon is simply the future indicative (xariou=ntai) thrown into past time: either form is equally proper in a final relative clause where the time of the governing clause is past. Cf. sup. § 1.
kai\ ta\ teleutai=a, closer definition of a)lla/.
pro\s xa/rin, ‘from self-indulgence’: the phrase generally means ‘in order to please someone else.’

prosi/ento, ‘acquiesced in.’ When at last the citizens at large could no longer be blind to the real character of the policy advocated by their pro-Macedonian politicians, they found things so far gone that it did not seem worth while to make any effort.

§ 68-72 Imagine your shame hereafter when you realise what you ought to have done. The Olynthians and the rest can now see the course they should have taken (68), but it is too late. If the ship is to be saved, every man in his place must do his duty while she is yet uninjured: efforts are futile when she is sinking (69). So with Athens. My proposals are ready. We must make complete preparations for war (Athens at least must do her duty) (70), and then seek to combine the rest of Greece in our support. At least we can delay our fate (71), and as our foe is but mortal, delay has its value, as had our efforts last year which checked Philip in Ambracia and in the Peloponnese (72).

§ 73-75 But do not call in the rest without acting yourselves. It is foolish to pretend interest in others' welfare while you neglect your own urgent needs. No: support your troops, make your preparations, and then strive to rouse the rest of Greece, as your prestige requires (73). No other city can save Greece while Athens hangs
back: it is you who must take the lead (74). If each of us sits idle waiting for others to do the work, he will never find these others, and we shall at last be obliged to tackle all the irksome tasks at once (75).
